talk.start.para: âA petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate assembled in the Parliament.

This is a petition of the citizens of Australia who draw to the attention of the Senate recent developments for the production, manufacture and sale of Genetically Modified Foods (GMFs) throughout Australia.

It appears that consumers are not adequately informed about the dangers of GMFs, nor are they (adequately) notified when GMFs are incorporated into products which are made available for sale in our stores.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate takes action, as a matter of urgency, to ensure there is a moratorium on the commercial production, manufacture, and sale of GMFs in Australia, until there has been adequate public consultation and debate on the issue and the full impact of GMFs is understood. This course of action will enable an informed decision about the sale of GMFs and therefore ensure the ongoing health and safety of the residents of Australia.

(1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Regulation and Promotion of Biotechnology, be established to inquire into and report by 1 April 2000 on the following matter:

A critical comparison of the strengths and weaknesses of biotechnology regulatory regimes in Japan, Korea, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, the European Union, Canada and New Zealand, with particular reference to:
(a) the implementation of labelling of genetically-modified food products;
(b) the suitability and adequacy of testing of biotechnology products;

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move that the following delegated legislation, a list of which I shall hand to the Clerk, be disallowed.

2. Customs (Prohibited Imports) Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No.202 and made under the Customs Act 1901 .

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ

para.inline: Accreditation Grant Principles 1999 made under subsection 96-1(1) of the Aged Care Act 1997

speech.para: The Principles establish a legal framework for the accreditation of aged care facilities by an accreditation body.

Paragraph 2.11(1)(a) requires an accreditation body, if it has decided to accredit a residential care service, to decide the period for which the service is to be accredited. However, subsection 2.11(3) provides that, once the accreditation body has decided to accredit a service, the period for which the services is to be accredited must be 12 months. It would appear, therefore, that 2.11(1)(a) might not serve any practical purpose.

Subsections 3.4(1), 3.12(1) and 3.21(1) allow an accreditation body to arrange for a review audit of a residential care service if it believes, on reasonable grounds, that there may not have been compliance with various Standards, or other responsibilities under the enabling Act. However, there is apparently no provision requiring the accreditation body to inform the provider of the service of the fact that it believes that there has been non-compliance.

para.inline: Customs (Prohibited Imports) Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.3)Statutory Rules 1999 No. 202

speech.para: The Statutory Rules introduce controls on the importation of the substance Erythropoietin.

The effect of new subregulation 5G(3) is that not only competitors in sports (within the meaning of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 ) but also anyone who comes to Australia as part of a competitor's entourage must obtain written permission from a Customs officer to import Erythropoietin (EPO). This requirement appears to apply even though the person is bringing in no more than has been prescribed for him or her by a medical practitioner.

para.inline: Therapeutic Goods Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.2) Statutory Rules 1999 No.209

speech.para: The Statutory Rules amend the Principal Regulations as a result of the establishment of the National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee.

New Subregulation 42ZCK(1) permits the Minister to terminate the membership of those serving on the Committee on a variety of grounds, in the Minister's discretion. However, there does not appear to be any provision for the decision to terminate the membership to be in writing, nor to be accompanied by a statement of reasons which have led to that decision.

New subregulation 42ZCY(3) permits the National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee to refuse to disclose, or provide access to, `information which it properly regards as requiring confidentiality for commercial reasons'. However, there does not appear to be any provision for external merits review of such decisions.

para.inline: Workplace Relations Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.5)Statutory Rules 1999 No.205

speech.para: The Statutory Rules give effect to the Government's response to aspects of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters concerning the role of the Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections.

New paragraph 60A(6)(a) of the Principal Regulations, inserted by item 1 of the Schedule to these Statutory Rules, creates a criminal offence of using information about voter rolls for `any purpose other than a purpose in connection with the election'. Since that offence carries a maximum penalty of $1,100, it may be thought that the content of the offence might be more fully spelt out than merely by the reference to `a purpose in connection with the election'.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Woodley, I ask that general business notice of motion No. 345 standing in his name for today relating to an order for production of documents be taken as a formal motion.
âIs there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThere is no objection to this being taken as formal, but I seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI thank the Senate. This return to order represents a serious mistake of judgment. Those who have been associated with the process of an aviation safety investigation know that the purpose of such an investigation is to identify human or systematic errors and to recommend changes to regulations and practice. Above all else, the aim of the investigation is to avoid the allocation of blame, lest future investigations become impeded by legal efforts to shield interested parties.

speech.para: One of the central elements in avoiding the casting of blame is to move from a draft reportâwhich outlines all that the investigators have found and provides their best initial effort at piecing together the storyâto a final report which may, following the processes of consultation with interested parties who have an involvement or interest in the incident under investigation, be different from the draft.

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation procedures manual identifies that interested parties, and only interested parties, get draft reports in order to identify errors, to allow natural justice and to promote confidence within the industry that reporting is open and accountable. Great care is taken in the final report to avoid references which are unfair or inaccurate.

Senator Woodley is proposing that the Senate should abandon this established and successful process and turn the class G airspace investigation into a series of media opportunities. He does not seek to await the completion of the report to its final stage but instead seeks the production of what I cannot emphasise too strongly is a draft report. Senator Woodley's motion would make it extremely difficult for the air safety investigators to do their job properly, and I believe it would not be either appropriate or responsible for the Senate to agree to it.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe opposition is supporting Senator Woodley's order to produce the draft report concerning the class G airspace trial. This is not a matter which would normally be pursued in this manner by the opposition. However, there are special circumstances relating to this draft report, and I am sure that if Senator Woodley was in the chamber at the moment he would outline them. They are that the matter of the class G airspace trial is a matter before a committee of this Senate, the Rural, Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. In terms of the consideration of the matter, the committee has asked to have access to the draft report and my understanding is that the minister has denied that access.

speech.para: More importantly, it has been suggested in hearings before the Senate, particularly by Mr Dick Smith, that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation was pressured in relation to this matter and that that pressure is reflected in the draft report. It is necessary for the Senate committee to have access to that report to make judgments on those claims. In the absence of the production of the document to the committee, this is the only means by which the matter can be pursued, hence the opposition will be supporting this resolution.
Motion (by Senator Bartlett, at the request of Senator Woodley) agreed to:

That there be laid on the table by the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services (Senator Macdonald), no later than 4 pm on 22 November 1999, the Bureau of Safety Investigation's draft report into the Class G airspace trial.

talk.start.para: âI present the report of the parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities on matters arising from the Company Law Review Act 1998 together with the Hansard record of the committee's proceedings, minutes of proceedings and submissions.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my remarks in Hansard .
Leave granted.

The Company Law Review Act 1998 which was passed by the Parliament in June 1998, altered the core rules affecting the way a company is run. The Act rewrote substantially the provisions of the Corporations Law dealing with, among other things, the registration of companies, company meetings, share capital and financial reporting by companies.

Prior to its enactment, the Act underwent an extensive process of parliamentary scrutiny by the Parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities (PJSC). In fact, the PJSC tabled two reports in November 1996 and March 1998, having examined the provisions of the Exposure Draft Bill and the final Bill that was introduced into the Parliament.

The Act incorporated many of the comments and amendments recommended by the PJSC as a result of its examination of the Company Law Review Bill 1997. During debate on the Bill in the Senate, the Australian Democrats and the Opposition moved a number of amendments which the PJSC had not had the opportunity to examine. This was regrettable because many of the amendments were passed into law without having undergone a process of public consultation and the rigours of parliamentary scrutiny. While a number of amendments and revised amendments to the Bill were passed by the Senate, additional amendments and issues not resolved during the debate were deferred until these could be examined in detail by the PJSC.

The PJSC commenced its review of the late amendments and proposed amendments to the Company Law Review Act in July 1998 following a request by the Treasurer. In general, there was considerable criticism of the process and of the lack of public consultation in respect of the late amendments to the Act which necessitated the PSJC review.

The submission of The Law Society of Western Australia reflects the views expressed by a large number of companies, business groups, professional bodies and practitioners of the Corporations Law: (and I quote)

para.inline: "The Society wishes to express its concern at the amendments which were introduced into the Act at the last moment. The Society recognises that the Parliament has the power to amend pending legislation. In the circumstances, the Society contends the power ought not to have been exercised in this case. The Company Law Review Bill, and its predecessor, were the subject of very extensive public consultation and comment, in which the Society and many of its members participated, both before and after release of the draft legislation in June 1995. Such a long and extensive public consultation was then abandoned without opportunity for further input at the last moment. The last minute amendment undermines the integrity of the consultation process by demeaning the efforts of those that participated and endangers their further participation. It is true that certain amendments had been the subject of discussion by some. However, without advance knowledge that the proposals were to become law, there was neither incentive nor opportunity to comment on them."

speech.para: The Committee's review was interrupted by last year's Federal election and then resumed earlier this year. There is insufficient time to outline all of the amendments and other matters considered by the PJSC so I will confine my comments to the more controversial amendments and issues. One of the main areas of concern raised with the PJSC was section 299(1)(f) which requires listed companies to report on environmental compliance with federal and state laws. The PJSC was told that the provision was vague and uncertain, with practical effects which were limited and counter-productive. For example, the requirement does not apply to the operations of Australian companies overseas, where many listed companies have substantial investments.

Section 299(1)(f) also requires entity rather than project reporting for mining and exploration joint ventures. Consequently, a stakeholder with only a nominal share in the joint venture is obliged to report on environmental compliance. The PJSC concluded that it was inappropriate for the Corporations Law to provide for environmental reporting in this manner and accepted the almost total unanimity of view on this point of submissions from the Australian business and legal communities. The PJSC is satisfied that a voluntary reporting system, as opposed to a statutory obligation, will encourage companies to achieve best practice in the area of environmental reporting. Accordingly, the PJSC recommended that section 299(1)(f) should be repealed.

A second controversial amendment was the requirement for listed companies to disclose in their annual reports the company board's remuneration policies, a discussion of the linkage between remuneration and the company's performance, and the disclosure of the details of the remuneration of directors and senior executives. While the PJSC agrees with the objectives behind the new disclosure requirements under section 300A, the drafting of that section was deficient in many respects. In fact, many submissions argued that the disclosures required under section 300A would produce only general statements of the obvious and would result in inaccurate and misleading information being disclosed.

A further point was that section 300A did not require the disclosure of a valuation of options granted to directors and executives as part of the remuneration package, although during debate on the amendment it was intended that the Law should require this. The PJSC found a large disparity in practice between companies in the degree of compliance with section 300A which was the result of the unclear drafting. This outcome was not the result of an unwillingness by companies to comply with the Corporations Law. Very simply the Corporations Law was unclear.

Given the increasingly large amounts involved where options are granted to directors and executives, the PJSC concluded that the Corporations Law should require the disclosure of the value of options in the total remuneration. To resolve the drafting inconsistencies and the inclusion of the value of options in the remuneration package, the PJSC recommended various amendments to section 300A and section 300 of the Corporations Law, which will have the effect of requiring the disclosure of directors' and executives' remuneration in all its forms. The PJSC has also recommended that the new accounting standard on directors' and executives' remuneration should require a statement by the board that discusses its remuneration policy and the relationship between that policy and the company's performance.

Another significant issue was the extension of the period of notice of shareholders' meetings from 14 to 28 days. In its March 1998 Report on the Company Law Review Bill 1997, the PJSC did not support the calls for extending the period of notice from 21 days to 28 days. The PJSC had considerable sympathy for those concerned that the 14 days was too short but was not convinced that the doubling to 28 days was either justified, necessary or in the interests of the company. The Committee recommended that the clause in the Bill requiring a minimum 21 days notice of meeting should proceed. The evidence put to the PJSC during the inquiry has reinforced its earlier view and recommendation. The 28 days notice has placed greater demands on directors and company management and has increased costs without any measurable corresponding benefit to shareholders. The PJSC concluded that the amendment which doubled the period of notice from 14 to 28 days has added considerably to costs and inefficiency in company meeting cycles. The PJSC also concluded that the increased use of electronic communication provides a more appropriate solution than extending the notice period for shareholders' meetings. Accordingly the PJSC has recommended that the notice period should be reduced to 21 days.

The final issue I want to address is the threshold requirements for requisitioning a shareholders' meeting. This matter was referred to the PJSC by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. The current position is that 100 members of a company, who together may hold only a small economic interest in the company, may requisition a meeting of shareholders, with the resulting costs being met the company.

The PJSC was told that this provision in the Corporations Law was open to abuse and inappropriate, given that the requisitioners may represent only a minuscule proportion of the company's members. In addition, the company is disadvantaged by the distraction of its directors and senior management from their core functions.

The PJSC also found that the proper purpose test in section 249Q of the Law did not provide adequate safeguards against the potential abuse of the requisitioning power. The PJSC endorsed the view expressed by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee that a 5% issued share capital test would be reasonable and conforms to overseas practice. The PJSC therefore recommended that the Corporations Law should be amended to provide that the sole test, to requisition a meeting of shareholders, is 5% of the issued share capital to be met collectively by the requisitioning members.

The PJSC also has made other significant recommendations in relation to a director's power to call a meeting, the disclosure of information relating to proxy voting intentions, the receipt of proxy appointments and other matters affecting company administration.

Before I conclude my remarks I would like to thank all of the individuals, companies, professional bodies and organisations which made submissions to the PJSC and witnesses who appeared before the PJSC during its public hearings. I would also like to thank all members and former members of the PJSC for their contributions to its deliberations on this important review of Matters Arising from the Company Law Review Act. May I also thank Committee Secretary David Creed and his dedicated staff for their efficient running of the Committee and this Inquiry and for their erudite assistance with my Chairman's first draft of this Report, which was well received by all Committee Members.
I welcome the general support of all members of the PJSC for the Report. I commend the Report to all honourable Senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI present report No. 371 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit entitled Aviation Security, Planning of Aged Care, Costing of Services, Review of Auditor-General's reports 1998-99 , and I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The document read as followsâ

Madam President, Report 371 informs the Parliament of the Committee's examination of the Auditor-General's reports on aviation security, the costing of services, and the planning of aged care services. The Committee held a public hearing in May this year to discuss these issues with the relevant Commonwealth agencies. I will briefly discuss each issue in turn.

The Audit Report on aviation security noted that the department had established a regulatory regime which ensured Australia's compliance with international standards. However, the report also identified areas where Australia's aviation security regime could be strengthened. The JCPAA focussed on risk management practices and auditing and compliance procedures. It is vital that security procedures address the danger presented by criminal behaviour at airports. Currently, the focus is on politically motivated violence but criminal activity is actually more of a problem. Our report recommends that security arrangements be reviewed by relevant Commonwealth agencies so as to maximise the effectiveness of police forces and airport authorities in combating crime.

The Committee also examined Audit Report No. 19 , into the planning of aged care. The quality and availability of aged care services is a very important issue for many Australian families. It is critical that the Commonwealth plans effectively to provide these services where they will be most needed. This is why the JCPAA has recommended that the input of local communities be harnessed when planning is undertaken. Local communities, particularly local councils, are uniquely qualified to advise the Commonwealth of their future needs in this area.

Currently, state offices of the Department of Health and Aged Care can choose whether to consult local communities. The JCPAA believes that this approach is inadequate. We have recommended that local council input become an integral component of the planning process.

Audit Report No. 21 reviewed the costing of services in Commonwealth agencies. With the adoption of accrual budgeting and the increasingly contestable environment in which agencies operate, it is vital that Commonwealth services are costed appropriately. The audit report found that there was scope for substantial improvement. Indeed, Committee members are concerned that costing systems are not sophisticated enough for the new public sector environment.

The JCPAA has recommended that the Department of Finance and Administration actively facilitate the development of appropriate costing methodologies. We support the contention that each agency should prepare a methodology that is suitable for its business needs. However, in the interests of both quality and consistency, we also encourage the Department of Finance and Administration to provide a suitable level of assistance.
May I conclude, Madam President, by thanking on behalf of the Committee those people who contributed their time and expertise to the Committee's review hearings.

I am also indebted to my colleagues on the Committee who have dedicated much time and effort to reviewing these Auditor-General's reports. As well, I would like to thank the members of the secretariat who were involved in the inquiry, Dr Margot Kerley, the Committee secretary, Ms Rose Verspaandonk, Ms Maureen Chan, Ms Tiana Gray, and Ms Maria Pappas.
Madam President, I commend the Report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Allison, at the request of Senator Lees) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 359 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: (1) That the Senate:
(a) notes that:

(i) the failure of the United States Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty sends a strong negative signal to the global community regarding progress toward nuclear weapons disarmament and international security, and

(ii) Agenda Item 76(R) of the First Committee of the United Nations (UN) General Assembly calls on nuclear weapons states to discharge their Article 6 Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty obligations without delay, and calls on all nations that have not done so to sign and ratify the Nuclear Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty; and
(b) calls on the Australian Government to strongly support Agenda Item 76(R) presented by Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Sweden, particularly in light of the above.
(2) That the text of this resolution be conveyed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), to the Australian Ambassador to the UN and to other UN delegations.

This motion is a very important one, and it goes to the question of Australia's action in supporting a nuclear weapon free world. The proposal by the First Committee of the UN General Assemblyâagenda item 76(R), which is referred to in the motionâbegan back in March 1998, when the Middle Powers Initiative was established by a network of international citizen organisations to encourage leaders of the nuclear weapons states to commit themselves to the immediate practical steps and negotiation needed for the elimination of nuclear weapons. The goal is to build the political will to achieve a nuclear weapon free world. On 9 June last year, the foreign ministers of Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, Slovenia, South Africa and Sweden launched a joint declaration called `Towards a nuclear weapon-free world: the need for a new agenda'. This group is known as the New Agenda Coalition. On 4 December last year, the UN General Assembly adopted this as resolution 53/77 Y by an overwhelming majority. The Australian government intended to vote against the resolution but ended up abstaining. I must say that this action encouraged others to do the same, and it turned out to be a crucial vote.

Now the New Agenda Coalition has drafted resolution 76(R) and is seeking the support once again of the General Assembly to create a nuclear weapons free world by putting the heat on weapons states. That resolution says, amongst other things, that it notes the many negative developments in the proliferation of nuclear weapons and notes a small number of positive steps taken on the road to nonproliferation. It draws on all the existing conventions, treaties and initiatives, and it calls on the United States and Russia to bring START II into force. This is the second strategic arms reduction treaty, which seeks by the year 2003 to limit the US and Russia to 3,500 warheads each, of which no more than 1,750 may be deployed on multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicle equipped submarine launched ballistic missiles, with the balance on single warhead ballistic missiles and/or bombers. On 26 January 1996, the US Senate ratified START II. However, the Russian Duma has not done so, and a substantial body of opinion in Russia views the treaty as giving the US a nuclear advantage. It calls on nuclear weapons capable states that have not yet done so to accede to the treaty on the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. It calls on states that have not yet done so to sign and ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, and it calls on states that have not yet done so to adhere to the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and to work towards its further strengthening.

It is useful at this point to have a look at the current state of nuclear arsenals around the world. By the end of 1997, estimates of the number of nuclear weapons in the five nuclear states were as follows: Russia had 22,500 weapons; the United States had nearly 12,000 in the US, 150 B-61 bombs and 10 NATO air bases in Belgium and Germany, and Greece, Italy, the Netherlands, Turkey and the UK also had US bombs; France had 450; China had an estimated 400; and the UK had 160. There are over 30,000 nuclear warheads alone in the world today. Two or more states have crossed the nuclear threshold nowâIndia and Pakistan, to name those two. Approximately $780 billion is spent every year on global military expenditure. Nuclear weapons continue to be very attractive to some states. There is an illusion of security and no doubt prestige, and the doctrine of deterrence continues to be upheld in many places.

The standstill of the START treaty process between the US and Russia is of great con cern. Also of concern are: the deadlock in the conference on disarmament; the 11 announced nuclear explosions in South Asia in 1998; the persistent concerns over North Korea's nuclear program; the impending sale of a nuclear reactor by Canada to TurkeyâCanada sold Pakistan and India their reactors; the failure just last week of the US to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty; and Russia's continuing adherence to the policy of nuclear deterrence, which began in 1993.

I would argue here today that not only should the Senate support this motion but in doing so it would recognise that there is enormous public opinion out there that says: (a) we are spending far too much money on nuclear weaponry; and (b) it does not have widespread support and people are very concerned about this issue. In the US and the UK, opinion polls showed that 87 per cent of those people polled wanted their governments to help negotiate a nuclear weapons convention. I have no doubt at all that, were such a poll to be conducted in this country, we would achieve the same kind of feeling in opposition to nuclear weapons.

In 1996, the International Court of Justice gave an advisory opinion that there exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all of its aspects under strict and effective international control. The antiballistic missile treaty is regarded as the cornerstone of strategic stability. It limits the US and Russia to two antiballistic missile deployment stations. Their thinking is to not advantage one over the other, thus allowing for a reasonably equal penetration by both arsenals in the event of war. Of course, that antiballistic missile treaty is now under threat with recent Russian complaints.

So I think the world is not a safe place from nuclear weapons, and I strongly urge the Senate to support this motion. I think we are not much closer than we were during the Cold War to seeing peace and seeing a nuclear free world. We must revitalise this issue in this country and we must act on the international stage. My motion calls on the Australian government to strongly support agenda item 76(R)âand I have outlined what that meansâpresented by Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Sweden, particularly in the light of the above, and that the text of this resolution be conveyed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, and to the Australian Ambassador to the UN and to other UN delegations.

It is an important ask and not something that I believe the coalition or the opposition should be afraid of. It is important because Australia must state its position very clearly on the world stage in respect of nuclear weapons. Clearly we must go forward instead of reverting to a situation where nuclear weapons become a serious danger to the future of the entire world. I strongly recommend support for this motion.

talk.start.para: âI say at the outset that the intentions behind the honourable senator's motion are applauded by the government. I think the disagreements around the chamber on this are relatively marginal. The government has, of course, made it clear that we are deeply disappointed over the failure of the US Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. One need only look a little bit below the surface to see the domestic political issues that are always in play around the Congress, particularly as we approach yet another round of congressional and presidential elections. I guess when you have got two-year cycles in congressional elections they are always not too far away. I have heard, I think, the Prime Minister and certainly the Foreign Minister making it very clear internationally that we are deeply disappointed.

speech.para: But I think it should be pointed out that, although the US Senate vote was a setback to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, it was no more than that. It is certainly not an end to the treaty. We should not forget that there are already 154 state signatories to the treaty. It is rapidly approaching the status of a universal treaty. Furthermore, because all five nuclear weapon states have signed the treaty, under international law there is an obligation on those states not to frustrate its purpose before it enters into force.

President Clinton has made it quite clear that he and his government will continue the United States' commitment, a commitment that has been policy in the United States since 1992, to not conducting nuclear tests. As Senator Allison pointed out, in the vote on the New Agenda Coalition resolution on nuclear disarmament in the First Committee at the United Nations General Assembly Australia last year did abstain. The government's position at the moment is that we will look very closely at this year's resolution, but we do continue to have concerns about it.

talk.start.para: âWhat are they?

âI will outline what the concerns are. They are not so much on the individual elements of the resolution. Many of these are capable of support from the Australian government. It is in fact the resolution taken as a whole. The basic premise is to call into question the commitment of the nuclear weapon states to the undertaking they made in the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, that is, to pursue negotiations in good faith on effective measures relating to nuclear disarmament. We as a government believe that by calling for a new agenda the resolution also presupposes that the existing nonproliferation regime has failed, and we do not accept that as a contention. More importantly, we do not regard that as helpful. Australia and the international community derive fundamentally important security benefits from the nuclear nonproliferation treaty and we do not want the treaty to be damaged by further polarisation and debate over nuclear disarmament putting at risk the security benefits of the nonproliferation norm which has been clearly established by that treaty.

speech.para: We do, as always, support practical, realistic proposals on nuclear disarmament which are capable of winning the support of all states and, very importantly, the nuclear weapon states. But the New Agenda Coalition has clearly failed to do this. We do want to see reductions in nuclear warhead numbers. We should not forget the progress that has been made. We should applaud that progress. I think at the peak the numbers, between the US and Russia, were 69,490 warheads back in 1986. That has been reduced to 36,100 in 1997. Under START II, total deployed warheads should fall to 3,500 each, with further cuts envisaged under START III. That is significant progress, and of course we want to see that go further.

In terms of the current negotiations and discussions, Australia is working with New Zealand and Mexico to bring a resolution on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to the First Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. That resolution will call on all countries which have not yet done so to sign and ratify the treaty as soon as possible. I think that demonstrates what I said at the outset, that is, there is very little disagreement around the chamber on what the outcome should be and that it is very much a matter of how that is achieved. I think those words clearly demonstrate the government's bona fides and position on this issue. For that reason, because there is a disagreement on how we move that forward, particularly at the UN General Assembly First Committee, the government will not be supporting the motion as it is currently worded.

talk.start.para: âThe motion that is now before the Senate does two things. In part (a) it makes a number of observations about, in the first case, the failure of the US Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty and observes that sends a negative signal to the global community. It then refers to agenda item 76(R) of the First Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, which calls on nuclear weapons states to discharge their article 6 nuclear nonproliferation treaty obligations without delay. They are the observational elements of this motion.

speech.para: The action elements of this motion ask the Australian government to take a stand and to strongly support agenda item 76(R)âpresented by Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Swedenâin order to have the United Nations carry a detailed and comprehensive resolution asking for international action to curb the spread of nuclear weapons and to start to wind back nuclear stockpiles. It specifically would, if carried, request the President of this Senate to convey the text of this resolution to the foreign minister, to the Australian Ambassador to the UN and to other UN delegations.

The Australian Labor Party support this motion and we will vote for it. What is particularly important in this motion is its action elements. There are now some 36,000 nuclear warheads in the world that we know about. That is an excessive ability to demolish the globe several times over. Australia is a non-nuclear weapons power and Australia is committed bipartisanlyâand I acknowledge this from the Howard government tooâto remain a non-nuclear weapons power.

Therefore it falls to us to exert our influence in world forums, such as the United Nations, to curb the influence of the spread of nuclear weapons and to reduce the threat to world harmony and peace that they pose, and to make the world a safer and kinder place to live in, one in which economic growth and the wellbeing of the peoples of the world can proceed without the shadow of the nuclear weapons silo falling over them. If we do not take that stand, we derogate our own self-interest as a non-nuclear weapons power and we remove from ourselves the ability to influence global debate on this central question. Therefore the opposition strongly believes that Australia should mark the spot as to where it stands and should use its influence in the world by building coalitions of like-minded nations to push for an end to nuclear testing and a winding back of stockpiles.

Since the end of the Cold War and the stand-off between Russia and the United States on nuclear weaponsâor between the East and the West, as it was often describedâglobal attention has wandered from the threat posed by nuclear weapons. It seems that since the end of the Cold War and the dramatic representation of that threat by the two reigning superpowers at that time, there has been an assumption that the world is a safer place. It is not. The threat is more dangerous now than perhaps ever before.

That is because there has been the emergence of a number of new nuclear weapons powers that do not have the ability to scruti nise each other's actions, arsenals and operational directives and that do not have the early warning devices. It has to be fairly said that these weapons belong to governments which are inherently politically unstable. Because of that, the prospect of nuclear war by accident is more real now than it ever was. And because of that, the prospect of nuclear war by precipitate actionâor to make some ideological, religious or developing nation's point to the rest of the worldâis more possible now than ever before. As a consequence, Australia, as a responsible country in this debate, should assert and use its influence to try to bring some coherence, organisation, scrutiny and, ultimately, control to that situation.

The item that the Senate is being asked to support is a long one. I think most senators are aware of it and I do not intend to read it; it would take too long to do so. It has a number of provisions in it which call upon the UN to take particular action. Again, these are too long to exhaustively quote into the Senate Hansard this morning but a number of them deserve particular emphasis. Let me turn to a couple of those. Part 4 of this item calls for the examination of ways and means to diminish the role of nuclear weapons on security policies so as to enhance strategic stability, facilitate the process of the elimination of these weapons and contribute to international confidence and security. It goes on, in part 5, to call upon the nuclear weapons states in this context to take early steps to reduce tactical nuclear weapons with a view to their elimination as an integral part of nuclear arms reduction, and to examine the possibilities for, and to proceed to, the de-alerting and removal of nuclear weapons from delivery vehicles.

It calls for the states to further examine nuclear weapons and postures, to demonstrate transparency on their nuclear arsenals and fissile material inventories, and to place all fissile material for nuclear weapons declared to be in excess of military requirements under International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards in the framework of the voluntary safeguards agreements in place. It goes on to talk about the nuclear nonproliferation treatyâfull scope safeguards, a moratorium on tests and the physical protection of nuclear material.

The last is not an insignificant item in the list of issues that should be taken up here. The possibility of the suitcase nuclear bomb being smuggled across borders, not just by international terrorist organisations but by international criminal organisations, with nuclear weapons being at large and traded on the black market due to the decommissioning of some of the former Soviet Union's nuclear stockpiles, is a real threat to international security and requires global action to prevent it.

A lot of comment and most of what the government have saidâand I acknowledge they said it fairly; I disagree with their conclusion, but the facts they put down are a fair representation in many respectsâabout this debate centres on the rejection by the US Senate of the 1996 nuclear nonproliferation treaty signed by the President of the United States, Bill Clinton. I want to deal with the US Senate and the rejection of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in a moment. In talking about the United States and its role in global military and strategic leadershipâmore importantly perhaps, in this context, its role in global moral leadership on the weapons issueâone tends to overlook other responsible nations in this debate.

We know that in the last two years nuclear weapons have been tested in Pakistan and in India. They are nuclear weapons states. They are building stockpiles. They may lack sophisticated means of delivery, but they are rapidly acquiring those. We know that North Korea and Iran are widely suspected of being secret nuclear weapons states or being close to achieving nuclear criticality. Those nations bear a major responsibility in this debate, too. The debate should not just focus on the superpowers but focus on those nations as well. They all share some characteristics. One of them is that the emergent nuclear powers tend to be developing countries described fairly as `poor' nations in the world that are diverting scarce economic resources to the acquisition of sophisticated nuclear technology, which comes at a very high cost. It is money which could be spent on lifting the living standards of people in those countries. In this debate it is always worth while making this pointâit is a salutary one.

In the early 1970s, international intelligence agencies strongly suspected that Argentina and Brazil were engaged in a parallel nuclear race. The suspicion was that neither country had designs on the world but they feared each other. In order to prevent war between them, so the theory went, they acquired secretly the capacity to build nuclear weapons. In the mid-1980s the cost to their economies of diverting scarce economic resources to do that was so great that they could not bear the weight. They diverted back and a trade treaty was signed which integrated regional economic development between South America's major economies of Argentina and Brazil. As a consequence of choosing trade not war, the economies and living standards of those people has dramatically improved.

If there is a lesson here for the cross-border conflicts between Pakistan and India, it is: make love not war. Engage in cross-border trade, grow your economies and offer a better living standard to your people. Do not divert scarce economic resources into the acquisition of nuclear weapons. It comes at a high price that your country cannot afford. The consequent knock-on effect is that millions of Indians and Pakistanis live in poverty.

At the back of this resolution is a higher purpose. It is indeed a worthy purpose to achieve global nuclear disarmament. The effect on the world would be better living standards, fewer people in poverty, less tension between nations and less envy between peoples as to the material standards of wellbeing, and wellbeing at moral levels as well. That is a fundamental question that needs to be remembered here.

Let me now turn to the debate in the United States Senate in which the US Senate repudiated the US President and declined to endorse his signature on the 1996 nuclear test ban treaty. I have here an excerpt from the Economist magazine of 16 October 1999. Their opening paragraph reporting this development is worthy of repeating for this debate. The Economist says:
The Senate's defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty is a humiliation for the Clinton administration, a pyrrhic victory for the Senate and a disaster for America's foreign-policymaking process.

That does sum up the outcome. It seems the numbers were mobilised on the floor of the US Senate for a host of reasons. People who had wanted to impeach the President earlier but had failed to get the impeachment up now sought revenge by repudiating him over a motion that he was seeking to move. With base political motive they voted in this direction. Others voted for a whole series of reasons that the government referred to as a post-presidential election focus on internal domestic issuesânothing to do with what the treaty was about or what the global significance of the treaty was about but rather about positioning in a presidential race due to start next year.

One hopes that, once that political baggage has been cleared off the stageâand I do express this as a genuine aspirationâthe US Senate can again approach the issue of endorsement of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty and find within its ranks the numbers to provide a backing for the administration of the President in adopting such a treaty binding the United States. Let me express as a postscript to that sentiment another viewâthat I think Australia should intrude into this debate. If that vote is taken to be a vote for the increasing sentiment one sees reported in US domestic politics for isolationism and for higher protectionism in the US economyâthat is, a moving away from participation in the world to isolating and trying to insulate yourself from the globeâthen that is a negative direction for the United States.

As one of the US's eternal friends in the world, Australia should, as a mate, say clearly to the United States, `Do not go down the isolationist road. As a friend, you have an obligationâas indeed we doâto play a role in world affairs and not to isolate yourself from them. That means providing military and strategic leadership in nuclear weapons control and disarmament as well as providing global moral leadership on that issue. That is an attitude not just confined to weapons but broadly expressed across a range of global issues, including integrating your economy with the world and opening up your economy to fair and free competition.'

We support this motion, which, if adopted, will advance the cause of nuclear weapons control at a time when the globe needs such an effort to be made. Nuclear weapons and arms control has ceased to be an issue that attracts public attention. As the world has become more complex, other issues have taken centre stage as the arms race and the Cold War have ended. As I said earlier in my remarks, while the most obvious manifestation of Cold War hostilities is off the international stage, the arms race is continuing around the world in a range of ways, which means that there are more nuclear weapons now in the hands of countries which are politically unstable and have axes to grind than ever before. The best advice the United Nations can give them, urged on by Australia, is to disarm and direct their attentions to growing their economies and benefiting materially the welfare of their people.

talk.start.para: âI agree with the sentiments that have been expressed in favour of this motion and congratulate Senator Allison for bringing it forward. It sadly shows a division between the majority sentiment in the Senate and the position of neutrality at best that the Howard government represents in world fora as well as in this place. This is simply not good enough, because it sells out public opinion in Australia. There is no country in the world where public opinion is in favour of nuclear weapons. The world's people are opposed to nuclear weapons. If there were a plebiscite around the world tomorrow, nuclear weapons would be outlawed by the sentiment of something like 80 per cent of the people on the planet. We have nuclear weapons because there is greed, belligerence and a failure of imagination, not amongst ordinary people but amongst those who hold the power and exercise it. That includes democracies and dictatorships alike.

speech.para: The recent vote on the United Nations resolution on nuclear disarmament, `The need for a new agenda', was hosted by, amongst other countries, our neighbour New Zealand, which is the only country to have comprehensively prohibited nuclear weapons and nuclear activities on its soil. There was a preponderant 114 votes in favour, there were 18 votes against, from the nuclear countries and their acolytes by and large, and there were abstentions from 38 countries who could not make up their minds that nuclear weapons should be outlawed, and that includes Australiaâno doubt part of the result of a very strong lobby, including emissaries from the United States and elsewhere, coming here to Canberra to lobby to not have this resolution go through.

One of the things we have to be clear about here is that this government is influenced by the fact that the uranium miners want to expand their exports into the world nuclear fuel cycle, and that is indivisible from the propensity for making nuclear weapons. It is an immoral process that we take part in there. The sale of uranium out of this country compromises governments in their ability to take a stand comparable to New Zealand's in opposing nuclear weapons, which is the wish of the majority of Australians.

There is a consistency in polls elsewhere around the world on such things as nuclear disarmament, support for UN resolutions on the abolition of nuclear weapons and so on. In Canada 92 per cent of people support it. In India, even following the media coverage of euphoria about the explosion of their nuclear bomb last year, 73 per cent of people do not want the country to develop nuclear weapons. In Norway support is 92 per cent; Germany, 87 per cent; Belgium, 72 per cent; and in Russia, 61 per cent of people want nuclear weapons abolished altogether.

In the United States, 87 per cent of people want their government to negotiate a nuclear weapons convention. But the Senate, calling on and abusing Christian sentiment, amongst other things, have decidedâfor reasons including those outlined just a moment ago by Senator Cookâto vote against the wish of the rest of the world that we move towards a comprehensive test ban treaty and the abolition of nuclear weapons. In the United Kingdom, 87 per cent of people supported a nuclear weapons convention; in Australia, 92 per cent; in Japan, 78 per centâand so on.
The sentiment is extraordinarily strong. And why not? The World Court itself in its advisory opinion of 8 July 1996 cited the uniquely appalling characteristics of nuclear weapons:
. . . in particular their destructive capacity, their capacity to cause untold human suffering, and their ability to cause damage to generations to come.
It added that only they:
. . . have the potential to destroy all civilisation and the entire ecosystem of the planet.

But there is a mind block among the powers that be that is not able to relate to life on the planet in the future. It is an armageddon fault in the brains of those people in power who seem to think that they have some form of immortality or that, if they press the button first, there will be no repercussions and that they will in fact be the last ones left on the planet when the nuclear weapons explode. It is an enormous dilemma. It is one of those things that causes me to be in favour of a world parliament so that there can be a better reflection of the feelings of the people around the world through a democratic system, rather than the current system which leaves that world opinion at the mercy of multinational corporations that have an investment imperative in much of what they do and that do not think about the wider human and ecological components essential to proper political decision making.

It is interesting to read what retired US Air Force General Lee Butler had to say about nuclear deterrence, which is the driving force for the stockpiling or the maintenance of nuclear weapons, both in the NATO countries as well as in Russia and China. He said:
(T)he theory of nuclear deterrence, the bedrock principle of US national security during the Cold War, is costly, wrong-headed and dangerous.
(Deterrence) evolved from an increasingly convoluted morass of unwarranted assumptions, unprovable assertions and logical contradictions.
This is the best thinkers in the United States having their thinking dissected by one who was part of their military establishment. He goes on:
By the end of the first decade of the Cold War, it had effectively served to suspend rational thinking about the ultimate aim of national security: to ensure the survival of the nation.

The United States alone has spent $A7 trillion or $A8 trillion on developing nuclear weapons. That outstrips such things as education, local security and the delivery of a lot of social security services in the United States. It is an indictment, again, of the way in which the world has failed, after more than half a century of nuclear weapons, to come to grips with this blight on our collective reputation.

I hope we get far enough in history that the world will be able to look back on this period and note not only the fight of those who wanted nuclear weapons but also the extraordinary public feeling against them and the ongoing campaign that is coming from a grassroots level. On that, I would like to note this book, entitled Fast track to zero nuclear weapons, which outlines the middle powers initiative, which Australia abstained from at the United Nations. It was disseminated widely in this parliament just last week by that noted former Western Australian Greens senator Jo Valentine, who was here to lobby for sanity as far as nuclear weapons are concerned.

I am appalled that we have a government that cannot come out against nuclear weapons testing insofar as they cannot come out in favour of this new middle powers initiative in the United Nations. We should be part of the driving force for this instead of, at best, sitting on the sidelines saying, `We are unable to make up our minds.' That is what the government are saying here today: they cannot make up their mind to support this extraordinarily reasonable motion. It is not an outspoken motion; it is simply calling for a message to come from this place to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Australian Ambassador to the UN and to other UN delegations to say that the Senate wants Australia to join the other middle power nations, for goodness sake, like Brazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Sweden.

Notably, South Africa had nuclear weapons and got rid of them. It is one of the four countries that has actually done what the rest of the world wants countries like Russia, the United States, China, Britain, India, Pakistan, Israel and Iran to do. I also note at this point that, at the moment, we have at the Lucas Heights reactor in Sydney at least 16 scientists working on a laser enrichment program which is going to diminish the cost of enriching uranium by about 90 per cent, if it fulfils its promiseâto use that word in a contrary or strange context. This means that nuclear weapons, for those who can get hold of this technology, will be much cheaper to produce. So not only are we exporting the raw materials out of this country; we are also engaged in and licensing experimentation which is ultimately going to flow on to help those who want to abuse nuclear weapons and who could hold the world in thrall of unimaginable terrorism in the next century, because we are not acting now. I support this motion. I condemn the government for not supporting it.

talk.start.para: âOh dear!

âIt is an extraordinary thing that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate cannot speak out in favour of this motion and that the Howard government are so far behind public opinion on this matter.

âIt is disappointing, as Senator Brown says, to hear the government say that it cannot support this motion. I thought that the government's arguments were very weak. For the government to say that it was supportive of individual elements of resolution 76(R) but not the resolution as a whole, seems to me to be an extraordinary statement to make, particularly given that we are one of those middle order states which have no nuclear weapons and that we entered into legally binding commitments not to receive, to manufacture or to otherwise acquire weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Those undertakings were made in the context of a corresponding legally binding commitment to the pursuit of nuclear disarmament by the nuclear weapons states, including the US, which seems to be the country which Australia is most afraid of upsetting.

speech.para: Senator Ian Campbell also said that the government applauds the progress so far on disarmament, coming down from 60,000 nuclear warheads to 36,000. A fraction of 36,000 nuclear warheads would be enough to wipe out most of humanity on this planet. So it is not good enough. We must use whatever means are at our disposal and we must join with other nations when initiatives such as this come up and do our utmost to see that that 36,000 arsenal of nuclear warheads is gotten rid of completely. That is the only way we can guarantee a safe and peaceful future for this planet.

Even though Australia is not a major player on the world stage in terms of nuclear activities, it must use whatever means are at its disposal to influence other countries. To say that this would call into question previous treaties and that the new agenda presupposes that the existing convention has failed is really quite absurd. Is Senator Ian Campbell saying that those other statesâBrazil, Egypt, Ireland, Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and Swedenâhave got it so wrong; that they have presupposed that the existing convention has failed? I find that an extraordinary argument to put.

It is disappointing. I hope that the government can come up with some other measure, some other step, that will allow us to go forward on this and to really make a stand. Whenever I see New Zealand's name amongst the number of countries which stand up against nuclear weapons in the world, I feel very proud of New Zealand because it is such a close neighbour to us but very sorry that Australia cannot follow the example of what is a very small nation but one which is unafraid to stand up to the rest of the world and unafraid to speak out about this issue. I often wish that Australia could find the courage to do what New Zealand does. Again, I urge the Senate to support this motion and I urge the government to change its mind about what I see as an intransigent position.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
