Is there any justification for the scare campaign mounted by those opposed to cheaper CDs? Is the minister aware of any alternate policy approaches? What would the impact of these be if they were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Tierney very much for that question because it gives me the opportunity to point out just what has happened since that very important legislation went through the parliament some 12 months ago. Top 40 CDs, which probably make up the great bulk of sales in this country, have gone down $4 to $5 since that time. Target department stores are now selling them for $24.95. Chaos Music is selling top 40 CDs for around $23. In fact, consumers can now buy Powderfinger's Internationalist for $26.90, Blink-182's new CD for $17 and the Corrs' latest album for $18.95.

answer.para: So there are obviously very big bargain opportunities as a result of this very important legislation. Of course, 80 per cent of Australian adults do regularly purchase CDs, so this has been very good news for consumers. What did we get beforehand? We were told not only that the sky was going to fall in but also there would be a massive increase in piracy. There was not.

talk.start.para: âThere has been.

âI am pleased to see that the wholly owned subsidiary for ARIA is interjectingâwe will come to her in a moment. We were told the domestic industry would collapse; it has not. We were told that the Australian industry would not benefit; it has. We were told there would be job losses of more than 50,000; of course the fact is that there are fewer than 5,000 people in the industry anyway. But, more specifically, we were told by people like Senator Lundy that there would be no winners from this proposal and that consumers would not enjoy cheaper prices. Mr Beazley said: `The Prime Minister has given his personal pledge that prices will fall, and we in the Labor Party and the consumers of Australia are going to hold him to it.' We are delighted that he has; it is one of his biggest achievements to date. Senator Stott Despoja said that the Democrats were not satisfied that the prices of sound recordings would fall if parallel import restrictions were removed. They have fallen, and you know it. If you look at what is happening in the industry, you now find people like Strathfield Car Radios selling Billy Joel's hits for $15.95. I am personally delighted with that. It would never have happened if you had had a Labor government.

answer.para: Senator Hill interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAs an Elton John fan, you can do just as well, Senator Hill, if you visit Strathfield Car Radios! I know that everyone out there who is interested in buying cheaper CDs will be forever grateful. That is why it is a tragedy that we had this huge scare campaign. Senator Lundy played the union card. She said that this will place at risk hundreds of jobs in the freight industry. If you believe that line you would believe that every tanker going up and down the Hume Highway was carrying nothing but CDs; don't worry about tankers and food distribution! Of course, nothing has happened at all. It has basically been an absolute damp squib to the point where we had the New South Wales Director of the Australian Music Retailers Association saying: `The legislation has had a very positive effect. I was surprised at how rapidly the Australian record companies adapted to the new way of doing business. They are able to change the way they operate so quickly; the consumer is better off and retailers are better off.'

answer.para: Doesn't that just show what a monumental scare campaign it was? Doesn't that show how it had absolutely no substance and how it spooked both Labor and the Democrats and that only this government was prepared to stand up and fight? We did not just go along to ARIA opening nights; we did not just want to get our heads on the television screen at all times; we did not just want to be standing alongside a few pop stars who made us feel young and important. We actually stood up for sensible policy changes. I say to the opposition: it is not too late; look at the facts and accept you got it wrong; come out on the side of the consumers for a change and stop pandering to vested interests. That really is where the Labor Party gets it wrong every time. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former South Australian senator Tony Messner. Welcome to the Senate.
âHear, hear!

âMy question is to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Aged Care. Does the minister recall saying on 31 March this year that the Productivity Commission's report into nursing home funding `raises a number of issues that the government will consult on and make a decision about in coming months'? Is the minister aware of the of concerns of government backbenchers from Queensland over the failure of the Minister for Aged Care to respond to the Productivity Commission report into nursing home funding and, as a Queenslander, does the minister share those concerns? Has he approached the Minister for Aged Care in an effort to get her to do her job and respond to the many issues raised by the Productivity Commission? Exactly what has the minister done since 31 March 1999 to ensure that a response would be forthcoming, as he promised, in the `coming months'?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âSenator Hogg is obviously referring to a newspaper article that was reporting on a party room meeting. I normally do not comment on party room meetings; in fact, I should not, but in this instance I will make an exception. I can confirm, Senator Hogg, that in the party room we discussed that unemployment was down to seven per centâthe lowest since 1990. We compared that with the Labor Party's unemployment rate of 11.2 per cent. We talked about the inflation rate being 1.6 per cent; it has now been less than two per cent for over two yearsâin fact it has been the best in 30 years. We discussed the lowest home mort gage rates in the last 30 years. We discussed the growing economy.

âOn a point of order, Madam President: no doubt those matters were discussed, and also Dr Wooldridge's problems with the MRI scam and all sorts of other issues, but this question is about Senator Herron's responsibilities representing the Minister for Aged Care. Consistent with rulings you have made, which are that answers must be relevant at least in the area in which they have been asked, I would ask you on this occasion to direct Senator Herron either to answer the question or, if he has got nothing to say, to sit down and take it on notice.
âI draw Senator Herron's attention to the question.

âI have a lot to say and it is good news. It is bad news for the opposition; I appreciate that they do not like hearing that. Specifically in relation to Senator Hogg's question, yes, I am concerned and have expressed that concern but, on the other hand, I respect what the minister is doing. Since the Productivity Commission report was handed down, the minister has consulted with all sides in relation to this issue. She is particularly mindful of the impact on the industry and on those older Australians who live in nursing homes.

answer.para: Another part of the good news that I can report is that this government has increased the funding for nursing homes by 42 per cent since we were elected in 1996. The Labor government spent $2.5 billion on residential aged care across Australia; our outlay in the 1999-2000 budget is to be $3.5 billionâa 42 per cent increase. The reality is, and Senator Hogg may not be aware of this, that the amount of funding that has gone to Queensland has increased. I was delighted when the minister told me that. It has actually increased as part of that funding and increased disproportionately.

The minister will respond to the coalescence part of the Productivity Commission's report when she has finished consultation. She had consultation with two industry groups this week, for example. The minister will give a considered response to that report, taking into account all factors. She will do it in her time and at her pace, because it is important that the correct decision is made. I respect the industry in Queensland and the approaches that they have made to me. I have certainly made representations on their part, as have all the Queensland senators and House of Representatives members. We are all waiting on that decision. But more importantly, we believe that the correct decision needs to be made and the correct decision has to be in the interests principally of the people within the nursing homes themselves.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in respect of my question on the statement that you made on 31 March, you addressed the part where you said, `raises a number of issues that the government will consult on', but you did not address the part where you said, `and make a decision about it in coming months'. Does the minister agree with Uniting Community Services which in relation to the minister's inaction on this issue has stated:

question.para: . . . older Australians deserve a better deal, especially in the lower income and remote areas
Why are we still waiting for a response nine months after the Minister for Aged Care received the report? I ask you to address that.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âAgain, Senator Hogg did not listen to my previous answer. I said that she was addressing it. She is having consultations. She had consultations this week. I think it is more important to make the correct decision than an ad hoc decision on the run, and I respect her for doing that.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to the Bulletin this week which draws attention to the Telstra floatâas the Democrats have done many times in this placeâand the fact that the federal government sold the first third of Telstra too cheaply; in fact, $16 billion too cheaply. Does the minister agree with Mr Fahey's remarks in relation to Australia's record on privatisation generally and the sale of the last part of the Commonwealth Bank specifically, when he said:

question.para: Never a greater conflict of interest have I struck in my life.

Why does the government continue to take and to pay hugely for the advice of investment banks when they have a vested interest in getting the share price down? Is this minister intimidated in setting the share prices, as Mr Fahey was, by threats from the global investment giants?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âNo. I do not think either of us is intimidated by what is put to us. Obviously there are people who have very substantial interest in the outcome of issues and they argue their case robustly. I can certainly say my portfolio has its fair share of players in that category. But that is a far cry from intimidation. I think it is perfectly legitimate for them to argue the case strongly.

answer.para: I read that article. I saw Mr Fahey's comments about conflicts of interest. I think your question suggested that we should not pay for this sort of advice and that somehow we should either expect it to be given for nothing or we should have had it offered more cheaply. This is all in aid of this broken record line from the Democrats: with that wonderful 20/20 hindsight, when anything rises in price after the float, by definition you sold it too cheaply. If you were listening to Mr Fahey in question time yesterday, you would have heard him when he gave the example of CSL which Labor managed to float for $2 and which is now at about $18. Quite clearly the Labor Party would not be pleading guilty to having deliberately underpriced it. It happens all the time.

The fact is that many people had confidence in the quality of the Telstra stock and were very much of the view, particularly taking a long-term perspective on it, that there was a lot of potential in the share price. You do the best you can at the time and we took the best advice that was on offer. Mr Fahey quite rightly draws attention to the conflicts that prevail, but the challenge is really to separate those out and to understand where people are coming from. He certainly gave a proper account of the process and one that the government very much defends. None of that in any shape or form justifies this line that Senator Allison has been peddling for years. These were the people who, as I recall it, told us to call off the float because they thought that we would not get the price we were asking for. They had absolutely no idea. I am sure you would offer your advice for nothing but I can assure you we would not take it.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, doesn't the Bulletin article suggest that your government is too weak to meet that challenge you referred to and to get a fair deal for the Australian public? Does it not suggest that you should forget about selling any more of Telstra? Is the Bulletin correct in saying that a public relations firm is being used to answer questions put to the federal minister on the Telstra 2 float? Is it the case that this PR firm is also acting for ABN, AMRO and Rothschilds? Who is paying for this PR firm to say what big investors want said and how much are they charging for the service?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer is that their clients are paying. Once again, I would be fairly confident in saying that the services would not be provided for nothing. Once again, the fact is that the Democrats do not believe in privatisation. They have no idea what it is about because they think that it is much better if you control the whole game. This is a huge area of risk with the uncertainty attached to new technologies.
âMadam President, I rise on a point of order.
âWell, you asked me whether we were too weak and whether we should not go ahead with privatisation.

âMadam President, my point of order is that the minister is debating the matterâthough in fact, not the matter I asked the question about. I ask you to direct him to answer the specific questions that I raised.

âThere were a number of questions within the supplementary question and in the time it is unlikely the minister will cover all of them. But I am sure the minister is aware of the range of questions.

âIf I had all day I would get on to all of them. But I was answering the question: shouldn't we forget about privatisation? The direct answer to that is no. It is very much in the interests of consumers. It is very much in the interests of taxpayers. It makes the company more efficient. You can look after all the things that you ought to be concerned about, like quality of service, instead of having an ideological obsession that opposes any form of privatisation. You ought to look at the rest of the world. You ought to look at what Albania and Cuba have done. I do not want to go on and on about it today. But you are not interested in debating the merits of it. You simply want to take the view that, firstly, you get it wrong whenever you go down the privatisation path and, secondly, if the price actually rises then you have got it wrong. I am sure you would say the same if the price went south. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Women's Representation on Advisory Committees

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Newman, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I ask: does the minister recall yesterday having no idea what Senator Lundy was referring to when she asked about the number of women on the Howard government's advisory committees on the GST? Is the minister aware that the ATO's Charities Consultative Committee has one woman member out of a total membership of 15; the New Tax System Advisory Board has one woman out of seven members; and the community sector panel of the GST Start-Up Assistance Office has only one female member out of a total membership of sixâgiving women a pathetic 10 per cent representation on these public committees?

question.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are too many senators on my right interjecting and Senator Newman and I both need to hear the question.
âDid the minister really not know what Senator Lundy was referring to yesterday, or was she just not revealing the Howard government's dismal performance on women's representation?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âLet me make it quite clear that the question that Senator Lundy tried to ask me yesterday simply referred to advisory committees and when I asked her which committees she was talking about, she had no idea. So how was I to answer that question?
âSenator Lundy should outsource her questions.

âSenator Hill is absolutely right. That is brilliant advice. Could you charge her for that advice? I think it is worth charging for. Yesterday I went away after question time to try to work out what it was Senator Lundy was actually talking about. I do have some information about this, and, if Senator West would like me to add to the sum of the Labor Party's knowledge, I am happy to do so.

answer.para: The government has been very strong. Since we have been in government we have been very determined to make sure that women are appointed to boards and committees that are within the control of the Commonwealth government. As Senator West would no doubt know because she has been in parliament a long time and she was in government, sometimes women's organisations do not get as many opportunities to be heard as they would like. Under this government they have been advising me and have been involved in consultation with this government for the 3Â½ years we have been in government. We are pretty proud of the record that we have had in appointing women to boards, committees and senior positions. I could bring in here a folder of women who have been appointed to senior positions by this government. I will pick out one statistic that I think is particularly significant and that is that the foreign minister appointed either 14 or 16â

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order. My question related to the membership of women, or the lack thereof, on the consultative committees in relation to the GST. The department of foreign affairs has, from my understanding, very little relevance to the GST. I would like the minister to actually refer to the New Tax System Advis ory Board or the community sector panel on the GST, not the department of foreign affairs.
âMinister, I do draw your attention to the substance of the question.

âMadam President, what I am so proud of is the high number of women who had been appointed by this government to head up Australia's posts abroad. Australian women would be very keen to know that, even if some of the noisy fellows on the other side of this chamber do not want to know.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There is far too much noise in the chamber and I would ask senators to abide by the standing orders.

âI turn now to the specifics of Senator West's question, which I am very happy to do. The Office of the Status of Women is continually involved in consultation about appointments to all sorts of boards, committees, advisory groups, et cetera. The New Tax System Advisory Board which Senator West has just mentioned has seven members of whom one is a woman, and that is Carol Schwartz from the Sussan Corporation. The Business Advisory Panel has six members, of whom two are womenâWendy Craik, the executive director of the National Farmers Federation, and Angela Ryan, the tax director of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. The Community Sector Advisory Panel has six members, of whom two are womenâPauline Iles, director of the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association, and Di Mildern, the chair of the Non-Government Schools Funding Review Committee. We believe in finding women who are appropriately skilled for the jobs that we ask them to do, and we are very committed to continuing that effort and improving the level of women on all the boards, committees and advisory councils which we ask to work for us.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that 72 per cent of employees in the non-residential community services sector are women, and 60 per cent of emergency relief applicants are female, why isn't there some representation on these committees, something relating closely to the number of women recipients? Why is the government not doing that? What action is the minister taking? She says they are taking action, but will she outline precisely what action the minister and the Office of the Status of Women have taken and are going to take to ensure that the government's stated commitment of equal representation on public committees is met?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âAt this stage our commitment is to do a dash sight better than the Labor government, and that is what we have been doing and we continue to do by all sorts of things, like the Executive Search Pilot Program to assist women into these activities. We have done a number of things. I have answered you here over and over again. I have told you when you would not listen. I find that when I try to give you the news of what the government is doing for the status of women, the tactic on the other side of this chamber is simply to make a devil of a lot of noise so that you do not have to hear.

âMy question is to Senator Amanda Vanstone, Minister for Justice and Customs. The Australian Customs Service's annual report shows a 50 per cent increase in the seizure of illicit drugs at the border. The minister and the Customs Service are to be congratulated on this performance. Will the minister outline to the Senate how the policies of this government have further strengthened the good work already done by the Australian Customs Service?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Tchen for the question and for persisting in asking it over the usual barrage of rude interjections coming from the other side who are most ungracious to a relatively new senator, but that is what we expect from the bullyboys on the other side. On Sunday, I had the opportunity to attend the commissioning of the third new Australian Customs vessel, the Holdfast Bay , one of eight vessels which this government has funded to renew the Customs marine fleet at a cost of $58 million. It will strengthen our marine response capabilities and is a very timely addition to our front-line defence. Australia is facing, as are other countries, unprecedented levels of organised criminal activity in drugs, illegal immigrants and electronic fraud. On this side of the chamber, we recognise those challenges and are doing something about them. Unlike the previous government, this government is prepared to put its money where its mouth is. We are determined that the Australian Customs Service will have the tools they need to do the job: $34.5 million to improve our coastal surveillance capacity in the Torres Strait; $35.4 million for much improved X-ray equipment for large scale container searchesâ

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Schachtâa former Customs ministerâwould be pleased to know that we are buying the X-ray equipment that was never bought by his government. We are putting $27 million into new technology to improve surveillance coverage which, when he was Customs minister, he failed to do; $6.5 million for increased demands brought about by the Olympics; and $124 million through the Prime Minister's task force on coastal surveillanceâall in all, a lot of extra resources to the Customs Service.

answer.para: The Customs Service annual report shows that seizures of illicit drugsâsometimes by Customs alone, sometimes in cooperation with the Federal Policeâhave increased by more than 50 per cent. For example, seizures of cocaine went from 78 kilos to 292 kilos, heroin went from 138 to 508 kilos and ecstasy went from 32 kilos up to 89 kilos. These figures reflect the success of the government's strategies to intervene at the border. Seizures of performance enhancing drugs have almost doubled, from 558 to 968 kilosâa very important contribution by the Customs Service. Not only do they protect us at the borders from drugs and illegal immigrants but on Monday we revealed an attempt which was foiled by Customs to smuggle 30 snakes and four iguanas into Australia from the United Kingdom.
Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe already have some over here, as Senator Newman says; we do not need any foreign ones! Customs often face a very difficult task. Last week in Sydney they seized a crocodile skull, a couple of monkey skulls, a giant scorpion, some deer antlers, some coyote fur, giraffe bone salt and pepper shakers, some clam meat and a couple of alligator heads.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThey could have gone over there to get some of this sort of stuff!
âOrder! While it is very nice to hear everyone so happy, we should keep the level of noise down.

âThe Customs Service are happy because they are better funded and better serviced by this government than they ever have been; unlike when the opposition was in government. They had no vision, no policies, no inspiration and no comprehensive law enforcement strategy whatsoever. You did not have it in governmentâit is one of the reasons you were kicked outâand you have not developed it in opposition.

âMy question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that pages 183 and 187 of the department's annual report, tabled yesterday, confirm what Labor has been saying on the Howard government's record on child care and the minister has been denying for some time; namely, that actual Commonwealth expenditure on child care has fallen again this year and that the number of long day care places in both the private and community sector has fallen? Will the minister finally acknowledge that her own department's figures prove that expenditure on child care and the number of places available to Australian families are declining?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe number of places available to Australia's families is not declining and the expenditure on child care has not been declining.
âAre you saying it went up?
âOrder!
âWhat does the annual report say?

âI am coming to what the annual report says because it is very interesting. I would like to make sure that Senator Evans, the opposition spokesmanâwho was not silly enough to ask this questionâunderstands exactly what has been the situation with funding on child care. The government spent $989 million on child-care support in 1998-99. That figure was published in the final budget outcome 1998-99, which was released on 23 September. Reporting expenditure for 1998-99 is complicated due to the creation of the Department of Family and Community Services on 20 October last year.

answer.para: The balance of expenditure on child care is in the annual report of the Department of Health and Aged Care. The department in fact is providing more accountable information than has ever been provided on both an accrual and a cash basis. Accrual figures for child-care support are at page 183 of the report and cash figures are reported in the financial statements. The government has spent $3 billion on child care in the last three years, which is 20 per cent more than Labor's last three years in office. The last year of the Labor government saw a reduction of $88 million less than had been projected by Labor as take-upâ

talk.start.para: âHas funding gone up this year?
âSenator Evans!

âSenator Evans obviously does not want to listen to the information. Perhaps he already knows and does not want anybody else to hear. In Labor's last year in government, money provided by the Labor Party was not taken up to the extent of $88 million. Surprise, surprise! The same thing happened in the last year. There was $88 million less taken up than was actually appropriated, the same as in Labor's last year, but the money appropriated was increased, and more expenditure has been made in the three years we have been in government than you provided. The only problem is you can't read financial statements.
âMadam President, on a point of order: Senator Evans shouted across the chamber the whole time Senator Newman was speaking. I ask you to call him to order.
âI had.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, but she did not address that part of the question that went to the number of full-time child care places and particularly page 187 of the report, which shows that the number of operational places by services in Australia for long day care has fallen from 194,600 to 190,300. Would the minister care to address that part of the question?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe number has not gone down at all.
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âOn 18 October, Senator Allison asked me a number of questions with respect to the education of children of East Timorese asylum seekers. I can say that a distinction needs to be drawn between two categories of East Timorese in Australia. There are those that arrived in Australia as a result of the post-referendum difficulties and those that have been temporarily resident in Australia for some years and who are seeking recognition as refugees and resultant permanent residence in Australia.

speech.para: The East Timorese that arrived in Australia following the recent referendum in East Timor hold temporary humanitarian stay visasâvisa category 449. This is a similar visa type to that provided to the Kosovars and brings with it a recognitionâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam President: it is competent for the minister obviously to read this into the Hans ard record. I did make a point earlier that it is much more appropriate that they either be incorporated or read into the Hansard record as opposed to tabled, and I appreciate that. In this case, Senator Allison, who I understand asked the question, is not here. This is another example where I thinkâunless other agreements have been reached that I am not aware ofâan incorporation would be more appropriate than what the minister is doing, in the absence of Senator Allison's, who asked the original question.
âAre you speaking to the point of order, Senator?
âMadam President, I did give notice to Senator Allison that I would be answering this at the conclusion of question time. This is an important answer which I think needs to be heard.
âIt is for the minister to determine. He may seek to have it incorporated or he may read it.

âAs I mentioned, this is a similar visa type to that provided to the Kosovars and brings with it a recognition of the special needs facing these people. School age children covered by this visa are educated within the safe havens in which they live. There has been no waiting period for access to these education services. Since 1992, however, a number of East Timorese have entered Australia on short-term visitor visas and subsequently applied for protection visas and permanent residency. These people accepted the conditions that applied to the other holders of such visitor visas, including a condition that holders of visitor visas will not undertake more than three months study while on that visa. This is a normal condition for visitors and is noted on the visa.

speech.para: With over 3.5 million visitors to Australia each year, it clearly would not be in Australia's interest to offer unrestricted study opportunities to visitors. To do so would have enormous implications for Australia's full fee paying overseas student program. It is also consistent with the government's approach to entry to Australia that the primary purpose for being in Australia should be reflected by the visa issue. Where a person applies for a protection visa, the Department of Immigra tion and Multicultural Affairs issues a bridging visa which provides the applicant with the capacity to remain in Australia lawfully while their application for protection is considered. It is important to note that about 80 per cent of applications for protection visas are rejected on the grounds that applicants do not meet the criteria to be considered as refugees. It would therefore not be sensible policy to offer free access to the full range of government services to visitors who may apply for this form of permanent residency while onshore.

There is a body of litigation before the courts affecting the East Timorese asylum seekers holding temporary visas. The majority of East Timorese on bridging visas are currently residing in Victoria. The Catholic Education Office in Victoria has indicated that schools do accept enrolments on compassionate and humanitarian grounds in individual cases which may from time to time include school age children from East Timor. The decision to charge fees or not depends on individual circumstances and can involve community or church sponsorship of children or families.

The Department of Education in Victoria has indicated that government schools are able to accept the enrolment of school age children on bridging visas provided supporting documentation from DIMA is provided to verify that the student is part of an application for a protection visa. Australia is providing educational opportunities for school age East Timorese children in Australia, whether through education programs for those students brought to Australia temporarily or through the offer of public education for those seeking permanent residency in Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Health and Aged Care: Fundraising

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âI was also asked a question yesterday by Senator Faulkner, and I will also reply to that in full. I have been asked to also read into the record a letter from Dr Wooldridge, the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I took up Senator Faulkner's matter as he put it to me yesterday. In relation to fundraising, the member for Casey stated in Hansard :

speech.para: Any money that has been raised has been raised in accordance with the Liberal Party's fundraising guidelines and has been properly disclosed.

In relation to candidate returns, the member for Casey submitted a candidate return for the 1998 federal election on 9 November 1998, which I have sighted. The candidate returns for the 1998 federal election are now on display for public inspection at the AEC in Canberra and capital city offices. I have now received a letter dated 21 October 1999 from the Minister for Health and Aged Care:
Dear Minister
In relation to Senator Faulkner's question yesterday, he states:
"confirmation by the Minister for Health and Aged Care that certain radiologists who have profited from the MRI Medicare rebate have attended fund raising functions for Dr Wooldridge."
Senator Faulkner hasn't read the transcript of Hansard very carefully. The two people referred to in the House of Representatives (most scurrilously and cowardly I might say) were as follows.
Dr Jack Best, who by imputation by the Labor Party in the House of Representatives, was appointed to the National Health and Medical Research Council because he had organised dinners for me.

Dr Best is, in fact, a public health physician and has nothing to do with radiology. Secondly, Dr Best has never organised a fund raising dinner for me. Thirdly, Dr Best was first appointed to the National Health and Medical Research Council under theâ

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order. Under the standing orders, it is quite explicit that, in question time and in answer to questions, ministers will not debate the matter. This is a matter clearly being debated. Secondly, the standing orders are quite explicit on another matter, that is, in answer to questions, you will not use that opportunity to make ministerial statementsâthe implication being that question time is for actually answering the questions put.

interjection.para: Under the guise of answering a question, we have both debate and a ministerial statement, with imputations. It may well be that the government feel embattled in this matter. They should. It may well be that they want to try to make a ministerial statement to clear the air and, if they do, that would be welcomed because it would enable the chamber to then debate it. But this device is a misappropriation of the use of question time and/or of supplementing answers to questions. It is appropriate that the matter be incorporated, as is the normal practice. If the minister wants to make a ministerial statement, he should seek leave and do so. But he should certainly be restrained, and refrain, from debating the matter as he is also attempting to do.

talk.start.para: âOn the point of order: Senator Faulkner asked the question and, in doing so, made imputations against Dr Wooldridge but, more importantly, also against two very well respected members of the medical profession. He did that on television and on radio; he made those imputations and defamed these people. When Senator Ellison attempts to clarify the matter and to put on record the record of these doctors and of their great contribution to society and refutes completely the imputations and allegations made by Senator Faulkner, the Labor Party want to stop that. They want to prevent people in the galleryâwe are not on broadcast at the momentâand those people who heard the allegations made by Senator Faulkner from hearing the truth of the matter.
âThat's not true.

âIt is true, and that is why you want to stop this being made public. You are pretty good at defaming people but, when we want to put on record the great contribution these people have made, you want to gag the Senate and gag the minister. That is why it is important that this very important answer be given and given fully.

âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy President: in question time yesterday, I directed a question to Senator Ellison about whether he had satisfied himself about certain matters. Of course, there were no imputations contained in the question and, if there were, I would have expected a senator in this chamber to take a point of order or Madam President, who was presiding at the time, to call me to order. Of course, none of that took place at all. That is, of itself, an imputation, but I do not really care about that. What I do care about is the fact that we now have the government using this device, which indicates its unwillingness to incorporate answers in the Hansard record. It is particularly inappropriate when you are dealing with an item of correspondence. I have no idea whether this correspondence is relevant to the issue or not because my question went to Senator Ellison about his responsibilities. It did not go to Dr Wooldridge.
âIt did.

âIt was not a question directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. The point here is that, particularly when you are starting to quote a letter, it is far more appropriate to table it as part of the record or incorporate it in Hansard , as opposed to the minister reading it into the record like thisâdeliberately using this device to waste the time of the Senate in this particular way.

interjection.para: Of course there is an opportunity for senators to take note of such answers, but the opposition has pointed out to Madam President that we think it is inappropriate that answers to questions or additional information in answer to a question be tabled after question time. I gather informally that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, agrees with that and has indicated that he would encourage his errant ministers not to table further information but to incorporate answers in Hansard. That is appropriate in this particular circumstance.

talk.start.para: âWhat do the standing orders say?
âI will get to that shortly, Senator Macdonald.

âWhen you are reading out a letter, surely the point is reinforced even more clearly that the matter ought to be incorporated properly in Hansard , as opposed to being tabled. I am not arguing that it is not competent for a minister to verbally provide more informationâobviously that can be done. But this is a deliberate abuse of process by Senator Ellison, who obviously has very little to do with his time. Hopefully, he will learn from this experience that he ought not to abuse the processes and forms of the chamber in such a way again.
âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy Presidentâ

âI was wanting to rule on this. There is in fact no point of order. There is nothing in standing orders that actually enables ministers to fill out an answer at the end of question time. It is something that has arisen from practice and the indulgence of the Senate. So, Minister, I would ask you to complete yourâ
âYou are on indulgence, basically, so why don't you behave properly?
âI am. Madam Deputy President, I was asked yesterday about the fundraising activities of the member for Casey.
âIt is not competent for you to answer it now. Sit down.
âIt is. I will continue with my answer.

âMadam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is not competent, without leave of the Senate, for Senator Ellison to continue this abuse. That is the point of order I am taking: is it competent for Senator Ellison to have the call without leave of the Senate?
âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy President: you have quite clearly ruled that there was nothing in Senator Faulkner's previous point of order.
âThis is a different point of order.
âIn the previous oneâin which case, of course, Senator Ellison should continue the answer that he is now three-quarters of the way through.
âSenator Macdonald, I think you should have listened carefully to what I did say, that it is with the indulgence of the Senate that ministers provide theâ
âAnd you are not getting it.
âHow are we not getting it?
âYou are not getting it until due process takes place.
âOrder! It is with the indulgence of the Senate and it is the practice of the Senate that ministers provide additional informationâit is not in standing orders.
âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy President: obviously you are correct because by definition you are correct. But on the same point of orderâ
âWhat is your point of order?
âI am speaking to the point of order.
âThe point of order has already been ruled on.
âI take it that Senator Hill is taking another point of order.

âObviously indulgence was given, because he commenced answering the question and there was no objection to it. That is in accordance with usual practice. If ministers have further information pursuant to a question that was asked on a previous day, the normal practice in this place is that they are welcomed to provide that information. The Senate appreciates the fact that they provide that information. It is a courtesy to honourable senators that they provide that information. In this instance, of course, the circumstances are slightly different because within the question there was obviously inherently a suggestion that Dr Wooldridge had been in some way abusing the fundraising provision.
âIt is not relevant. The question was directed to Senator Ellison.

âThe question was directed to Senator Ellison to satisfy himself as to certain circumstances relating to the behaviour of Dr Wooldridge. It was implied within the question that there was some misbehaviour on the part of Dr Wooldridge. If it was not so implied, the question would not have beenâ
âWhy didn't you take a point of order, if there was such an imputation?

âSenator Faulkner is missing the point. He technically was able to ask the question in the form that he asked it. We all know how to do that. But the implication within it was that there had been some misbehaviour. That is why it was asked. That was the politics for the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. What is extraordinary is that, when the minister comes in here and seeks to provide the additional information, the Labor Party now attempts to prevent him putting that information before the Senate in full today so that the defence of Dr Wooldridge can be broadcast to all honourable senators interested in the matter today.

âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy President: I have indicated informally to Senator Hill after the last couple of question times my concern about the practice that has been occurring in relation to the way ministers have been providing additional answers to questions. I have indicated to himâand I made this point procedurally through the device of a point of order on a previous sitting dayâthat the normal way this has occurred is for answers to be incorporated in Hansard . I do not believe they should be tabled, and I think most senators would agree it is appropriate that material be incorporated. That is true on this occasion. It should be incorporated.

interjection.para: This is an abuse of process. If there is a view that there is some other matter in relation to my question or my behaviour or anybody else's that should be taken further, there are other forms of the house that can be used to allow that to take place. This is an abuse. It is not the ordinary practice. It is not the normal practice, which I am very keen, as I think the record shows, for ministers to conform to, that is, to incorporate answers. Probably this minister has indicated informally, because he does not care about accountability, that he will not provide an answer if he can only incorporate it. So be it. That is a matter for this particular minister. But I believe he requires leave for this. If a minister is to behave in this way, I think that you, Madam Deputy President, should seek the view of the Senate in relation to whether leave should be granted. When you do that, on this occasion leave will be refused because the minister is abusing the forms of the house.

talk.start.para: âOn the point of order: if Senator Faulkner wants to express what he understands to be acceptable practice, I want the same right to do so myself. In relation to these answers, ministers, as we know, have a right to table them. Honourable senators, however, generally prefer that the content be incorporated so that there is more ready access to that information. I think that one should meet that reasonable request of honourable senators. Where an answer or additional information is brief, it is also common practice for that simply to be read in rather than incorporated. Where it is lengthy, it would normally be incorporated. But where it is an answer to an implicit attack upon the personal behaviour of an individualâin this case, Dr WooldridgeâI would have thought that Senator Ellison would have every right to read into the transcript Dr Wooldridge's answer, and to do so at the first available opportunity. The fact that Senator Faulkner believes that he should not have such a right causes me considerable concern.
âHe should incorporate it or table the letter, and it should be on the public record.

âOrder! Senator Faulkner! Order! It is the practice for ministers to provide the answers at the end of question time. It is done with the indulgence of the Senate and it is the normal practice in this place that, where it is a long answer, it is incorporated. I would ask the minister to speedily wind up his giving of the oral answer, please. He has had a lengthy time.

âMadam Deputy President, I wish to take a point of order as well. I refer to standing order 203 and I take this point of order purely and simply because in the previous point of order Senator Faulkner made the point that, if in fact the point of order was not taken at that particular time, his question should be considered to be fair and legitimate and aboveboard. He made that point on a couple of occasions.

interjection.para: I take this point of order because I believe that, under standing order 203, the Leader of the Opposition's behaviourâparticularly when our leader, Senator Hill, was speakingâwhen he was shouting across the table to Senator Macdonald and Senator Ellison was totally out of order, a total breach of standing orders. His own position in his argument that he put before us at that particular time was that in fact, if a point of order was not taken and that was not challenged at that particular time, his activity was aboveboard; it was legal under standing orders and it was acceptable behaviour in this particular chamber.

I do not believe it was, Madam Deputy President, and I believe that, on that basis and on what he said on the previous point of order, he should be brought to order in terms of his particular behaviour and that screaming across the chamber that occurred at that particular time, disrupting our leader and being quite unfair in terms of what he said as far Senator Macdonald and Senator Ellison were concerned.

talk.start.para: âI called Senator Faulkner to order. He has come to order. There is no point of order. If yesterday something was considered to be unparliamentary, I am in no position to be able to judge on that now.
âHe is misbehaving and he has been misbehaving.
âOrder! Senator Crane! The whole chamber's behaviour has not been particularly edifying.
âI had not said a word until I took a point of order.
âYou should be quiet.
âYou know your behaviour was disgraceful.
âOrder!
âI rise on a point of order. The audible interjection of Senator Winston Crane is an offence to the chair and should now be withdrawn forthwith with apologies.
âI did not interpret it as being directed at me. I interpreted it as beingâ

âOrder! Senator Cook! Senator Crane, resume your seat. I am on my feet. I interpreted that interjection as one of the continuing disorderly interjections that are taking place across the chamber between honourable senators. I did not interpret it as being directed at me, but I would ask all sides to come to order and I would ask Senator Ellison to wind up his answer.

âOn the point of order, Madam Deputy President: it is not competent for Senator Ellison to add to his answer or provide this information without the leave of the Senate. He has leave to incorporate his answer and any supporting material he cares to from Dr Wooldridge or from anybody else.

interjection.para: You would be aware, Madam Deputy President, that in relation to the incorporation of answers to questions, the opposition does not insist on seeing the material. Anything you want to add to an answer can go into Hansard via incorporationâthat can occur now. But I do not believe he can do this without leave of the Senate. He can incorporate and he will get leave of the Senate to do so, as far as I am concerned andâI am sureâas far as all senators are concerned. He can table anything he likes without leave. I think it is more appropriate to incorporate it, and he will get leave to do that. I do not think he can speak without leave, but I ask you to rule on that specific point.

talk.start.para: âSenator Faulkner, I am going to rule that this is getting to be a very long answer and therefore getting to be very close to being a statement which would require leave. That is why I have asked you to wind up or seek leave, Minister.
âOn a point of order: how do you come to that?
âIt is practice and indulgence, Senator Hill.
âThank you, Madam Deputy President. The letter continues:

speech.para: Thirdly, Dr Best was first appointed to the National Health and Medical Research Council under the Labor Government by Graham Richardson as Health Minister. I reappointed him.

The second person who they claimed has had fund raising dinners for me was Dr Ronald Meikle. Dr Meikle has never organised a fund raising dinner for me. He informs me the only function he has attended was a Melbourne Cup Calcutta in 1995.

With respect to the disclosure of monies, perhaps Senator Faulkner is judging me by his own standards. I would have thought the answer is entirely self evident. The candidate returns for the election held on 3rd November 1998 contain the following advice from the Australian Electoral Commission:
. A donation received by an endorsed candidate, but passed to the party, is not required to be disclosed in this return.

If Senator Faulkner wishes to make these scurrilous and derogatory allegations that impugn people's motives over matters relating to money, the government would be quite at liberty to examine the role of individual, senior members of the Labor Party and certain corporations, or the role of the ALP more generally with a particular industry.

Senator ELLISON

It is reasonable to give leave for these sorts of matters but it is normally done, I might say, after taking note of answers to questions. Isn't that the case? Is this in relation to a question?
âNo, it is in relation to an order.
