As Senator Coonan said, they are attempting to politicise an issue which is untimely and inappropriate in the current situation. I think it is also very cynical. Rather than trying to constructively fill the policy vacuum in their party platform, Senator Jacinta Collins's bill is an attempt to attack the reform of workplace relations via the backdoor of politicising Australia's peacekeeping commitment to East Timor.

One can see how ridiculous this is. It is just plain crazy. Despite the apparent intention behind Senator Collins's bill, it is a plain old-fashioned attack on the initiatives undertaken by this government in promoting flexible workplace agreements. It is clear that the Labor Partyâthe dinosaurs on the other sideâwant to step back in time and go back to the Dark Ages of mass legislation and the coercion of employers rather than allowing employees and employers to come to flexible agreements on things like Defence Force service.

Senator Coonan and a number of my colleagues have pointed out that in the bad old days of the Accord, the then industrial relations systemâ152 federal awards out of a total of 3,000, of which 50 per cent were in the Public Serviceâhad some reference to reserve leave entitlements. That is approximately five per cent of all awards. The Labor Party come in here now and indicate what they want to do, when they had 13 years in government. If they were so concerned about the rights of reservists, especially with regard to pay, they would have done something about it in 13 years in government. Senator Coonan went over this in detail, but I think it is worth reiterating that five per cent of awards made reference to leave entitlements for reservists.

talk.start.para: âHow many employees?

That is what we care about on this side of the chamber. The opposition talk about numbers; we talk about individuals on awards who had no rightsâthe rights the opposition say they want to put in place now with regard to their activities as reservists.

We are telling it like it isâlike their policy was. Only 152 federal awards out of 3,000 had some reference to reserve-leave entitlements. There were individuals on awards, maybe only a small number, who did not have leave entitlements. It is crocodile tears on the other side. It is all false: let's have a go at this now; let's make a political issue while our troops are overseas.

speech.para: I know what the two reservists on my staff think about this legislation. I know what they think about what Senator Collins is trying to do. I have two young men on my staff, both of whom are reservists, both of whom have a great commitment to Australia and both of whom think this is absolutely ridiculous. Those are the views of two young reservists on my staff. I do not know how many there are on the Labor side but I have at least two on my staff.

Under Labor's compulsory complex system, there was no comprehensive coverage across the award system of young peopleâmen and womenâwho wanted to participate in the reserve forces, so why should we go back to that system now? Labor want us to go back to a period of complex industrial relations which failed to promote job growth and which saw record levels of unemployment at 11 per cent. Small business after small business came to us saying, `We can only employ our families because, under the current industrial relations system, we cannot afford to employ other people. It is too costly, it is too difficult and we are not prepared to do it.' So they held back from creating jobs, except for family members basically, and they ran their small businesses on the smell of an oily rag because the industrial relations system under Labor was so unworkable for small business. Labor would have us go back to record business collapses, high inflation, low productivity and record high levels of industrial disputes.

People on this side of the chamber, and those who have supported us, do not want to see those dark days again. This bill put forward by the Labor Party will put us back to those dark days. It is about introducing more allowable award matters and thereby reducing the flexibility and simplicity of the new system introduced by this government, which has seen unemployment fall to seven per cent.

Senator Jacinta Collins interjectingâ

As I was saying, this act, along with the Defence Act 1903, ensures the protection of Australia's workers by imposing fines under the criminal law against employers who seek to take action against them because of military service. This, coupled with a workplace relations system that allows employers and employees to negotiate flexible working arrangements, ensures that workplace agreements continue to meet the need for reservists to have Defence Force leave with the full support of their employers. I want to refer to a comment made by Minister Bruce Scott in the other place. He said:

speech.para: The Labor Party are saying that we should have made reserve leave part of the Australian workplace agreements. The fact of the matter is that there are now more reserve leave provisions in those agreements than there were in the awards. When I talk to the people out there in business, many of whom employ reservists, they say, `We would rather cooperate with the government and cooperate with the Defence Force than be coerced into employing someone and give them that leave through the award system. We would rather work cooperatively with the reservists rather than be coerced.' That system is working.

We know that the Commonwealth Bank have it in their Australian workplace agreements. Telstra have it in their agreements. The Northern Territory administration have it in their agreements. We in the coalition are about encouraging Australian businesses and organisations to support their employees' community service. But what about the ALP? What are they doing to provide policies which will provide similar outcomes? Absolutely nothing. As I said, they are still in a policy vacuum. If this bill represents any idea of what their policies are going to be like, then I can only pity the `true believers', because their beliefs are absolutely misplaced.

I know a number of my colleagues have referred to this interview with Mr Beazley on 6PR, but it has only recently been drawn to my attention. I could not believe it. InterviewerâWould it work like this, that if you need, say, two weeks off, you get paid leave from your employer? Is that how it works?
Mr BeazleyâYou'd get leave from your employer.
InterviewerâYou don't get paid leave?
Mr BeazleyâThat would be paid byâthe Army would give you pay while you're in there and so you've just got the right to leave there.
InterviewerâOK. So it's unpaid leave, in other words?
Mr BeazleyâYes.
InterviewerâIt's paid because the Army pays you.
Mr BeazleyâYes, that's right.

Mr BeazleyâYes, that's right.

InterviewerâNonetheless, I suppose you'll have those in industry saying, well, it's all very well and good but I've got to get somebody else to replace that person while they're away and that's going to cost be dough.
Mr BeazleyâYes, well, that's right. Sorry. Look, mate, I might have misled you there. It would be paid leave, in a sense, like your annual leave, that sort of thing.
InterviewerâSo it's paid leave?
Mr BeazleyâPaid leave, yes.
InterviewerâBut that's double-dipping, isn't it?
Mr BeazleyâNot particularly. They don't get paid huge amounts by the Defence Department.
InterviewerâBut they're still being paid by their employer, plus they're going to get money from the Defence Department.
Mr BeazleyâThat is correct but that's what the case has always been.

InterviewerâWell, I get back to the question then: Can you understand why employers even more so then would be upset because they say, "Well, all right, I'm losing employee X for two weeks and I've got to replace that person and pay someone accordingly"?

Mr BeazleyâOh yes. And that's why it's important that it be incorporated in an award. You take a thing like that out of awards and it's very unlikely that people are actually going to be supportive of it.
InterviewerâAll right. Well, what chances do youâ
Mr BeazleyâOh sorry, mate, I've misinformed you again. It is unpaid.
InterviewerâOh, OK.
Mr BeazleyâI've got a bloke in here who's sort of waved his hands all over the place and said that that was paid, so in fact as I originally thought, it is unpaid.
InterviewerâRight, OK. I think it would have beenâ
Mr BeazleyâI thought I must have made a mistake when I initially mentioned it to youâthe arm wavingâbut I hadn't made a mistake, it was unpaid.
InterviewerâWell, that's not so bad, because it would have been a case of double-dipping, but that's not the case so that's fine.
If anybody knows whether Mr Beazley knew whether the leave was paid or unpaid after that, I will give them a prize.
Senator Coonan interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAs Senator Coonan said, `He wasn't waving.' The adviser was waving, but Mr Beazley was drowning. What a performance from the Leader of the Opposition. He has been a Minister for Defence and he does not have a clue. He had a debate in his party room about a bill they are going to put through and he does not have a clue whether reservists are paid or unpaid by their employers. He does not know. He has to second-guess because someone is waving at him outside the interview room. I can remember when opposition leaders on our side of politics made a mistake and they were vilified. Here we have the Leader of the Opposition, who has been a Minister for Defence. That is the bit I cannot believe. No wonder the country went to the dogs when they were in power.

âMr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This matter is tedious repetition. It has been raised by every speaker from the government so far. It is tedious repetition of the press release from the minister for misrepresentations.
âOrder! Senator Collins, refer to people by their proper title.
âI will withdraw that. Just to clarify the point, I should say Minister Reith.

âThere is no point of order, because I do not believe that Senator Patterson is repeating any statements that she has made earlier in her speech. It is her responsibility to make any speech she chooses to make.
âI can understand why Senator Collins is sensitive. I would be sensitive too. If my leader had done an interview like this, I would be so embarrassed.
âHugely embarrassed.

âI would be hugely embarrassed. She has to try to explain what her leader was sayingâwhen he had been a Minister for Defence. There might have been an excuse if he were a new shadow minister having just taken on the portfolio, but that performance was something like that of the muddle-headed wombat. That would have been okay on the ABC show that we all used to listen to when we were kids: you knowârow, row, row; the Argonauts.
âA wave.

âA wave from the Argonautsâand the muddle-headed wombat has to get the story right. It deserves reiterating by every speaker on this side to just demonstrate how lacking in detail, how lacking in policy and how uncoordinated and undisciplined the other side is. If the Leader of the Oppositionâa former defence ministerâcannot get the policy story right for his own party's billâ
âHe was right.
âOrder! Senator Collins, you will have a chance to debate the issue later.

âAs I said before, Mr Acting Deputy President, when you start to put the pressure on, when you start to put the heat on, when you start to show that they do not know what they are talking about, all they can do is shout louder and interject more because they do not like what they hear. As I said, if the Leader of the Opposition cannot get the policy story right, how can we expect the ALP ever to get the whole policy story right? In returning to the bill before the chamber, let me look at its practical effect.
âGood idea.

âI wanted to talk about the Leader of the Opposition's absolutely appalling performance on 6PR. This bill will not result in any concrete gains for Australian workers. All it does is enable awards to provide for such matters. It will mean no material benefit for Australian workers. In no way will it dramatically increase the number of reservists available to the defence forces. In no way will it provide any further support to Australia's ability to maintain its commitment to the INTERFET forces and the people of East Timor.

speech.para: The reality is that employers have been supporting the defence reserves under the current workplace agreement arrangements, which provide flexible, workable and mutually agreeable arrangements for Australian business and employers. The simple fact isâ

âThe simple fact is that Labor, the unions and the ACTU have consistently opposed award simplification and the empowerment of workers to negotiate their own rewards. This was clearly shown by their own shadow minister for defence science and personnel, Mr Laurie Ferguson, on 11 May 1999 in the other place when he said:

these people must have come out of the arkâ
prevents reservists from obtaining defence leave as an award condition.
Mind you, he does not actually say that only 152 awards out of 3,000 refer to reservists leave. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Defence Force Service and Training) Bill 1999 proposes to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996. Its purpose is, purportedly, to ensure that leave for participation in service and training as a member of the Australian Defence Force reserves is one of the matters which may be taken to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for conciliation and arbitration. I said `purportedly' because the real purpose of this bill is of course quite different from what its subtitle describes. Let me say at the beginning that the Liberal Party has always acknowledged and cherished the contributions and sacrifices ordinary Australians have made and are continuing to make for the welfare of our nation by service in defence of it. Defence of the realm is a fundamental issue to this party and this government.

speech.para: It is a historic fact that when the Howard government came to office in 1996 it was presented with a gift of a $10 billion black hole in the budget, courtesy of the Labor government and its last Minister for Financeânone other than Mr Beazley, now the Leader of the Opposition and the proud sponsor of this bill. I draw the Senate's attention to this coincidence of Mr Beazley's participation. It is actually not a coincidence at all, because there is even more to it than that. Mr Beazley was in fact the Minister for Defence in a previous Labor government, when he presided over the decimation of Australia's defence capability on the basis that Australia was not under any foreseeable military threat. I understand `foreseeable' is a term referring to 50 years.

The situation has changed. We can understand that Mr Beazley would now be desperate to be on record as a person who cares about the members of our defence forces. What better way to do itâa totally costless and totally irresponsible wayâthan to put forward a legislative proposal like this bill. He does not have to pay for anything. He does not even have to make sure it goes through. What we have here is a caring, want-to-be national leader. All he wants for the nation is to make sure that the jobs of reservists are protected. Who would not be moved by his concern? However, the right of a reservist is already protected by legislationâby sections 8 and 9 of the Defence (Re-establishment) Act of 1965. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that it is an act of 1965. Under this act, employers are prevented from penalising their employees because of their service in the armed forces reserves. Under this act, employers would be charged with a criminal offence if they attempted to do so.

It is important to note that not only is this legal protection provided but also it is an historic fact that these sections of the act have never needed to be relied on before. In other words, Australian employers are much more compassionate about our nation's defence than the Labor Party is prepared to credit them with. Charity has never been a strong suit with the Labor Party, has it? It is more a case of `If you see a head, kick it as hard as you can.' But let us be charitable about it. Is the Labor Party merely being misguided in their enthusiasm to provide additional legislative protection? Not at all. This bill actually proposes to add an allowable matter to the awards. This is the real purpose of the bill: not concern over the welfare of the reservists but the addition of another matter to be considered in the awards.

The real purpose of this bill is to perform another last-ditch act of sabotage against the government's workplace reform programâreform that is urgently needed to bring Australia into a position where it can face global competition in the 21st century. I might add that the need for this reform was recognised by the Labor Party, even though they will be hard pressed to admit it, because this reform process was commencedâalbeit in a half-hearted and half-cocked mannerâback in 1991 by the Labor government. What this government proposed in the 1996 Act, unlike the current bill before the parliament, takes that reform process to its logical conclusion.

This reality is highlighted by Mr Beazley's obvious confusion about the actual status of a reservist's job. For Senator Collins's peace of mind, I will not repeat Mr Beazley's performance on Radio 6PR, in case she is moved to complain again. But the reality is that the issue brought up by this bill is not at all that of the welfare of the reservists.

talk.start.para: âI raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would like Senator Tchen to read it again because I did not hear it the other 10 times. I would honestly like him to do it again, and I think he should feel free to do it.
âSenator Quirke, there is no point of order.

âWith your permission, Mr Acting Deputy President, I think I do not need to indulge Senator Quirke. I suggest that Senator Quirke read today's Hansard in detail. At no stage has Senator Quirke asked about the description of Mr Beazley's going back and forth, saying, `I'm sorry. It will be paid. It won't be paid' and the people waving at him from outside the broadcasting booth.

speech.para: I would like to talk about something that is a little more serious. I do not want to take the Labor Party to task about how inadequately they are trying to represent the people of Australia, because I understand that the function of an opposition party is to make noise rather than to actually propose policy which the nation can follow. I want to come back to this question of workplace reform. It seems to me that the fundamental issue of the Workplace Relations Act 1996âI know Senator Collins is an expert in this area so I will not try to match her on the intricate details of itâis quite simple. Australia has an almost unique system of workplace relations. It is something that has been built up over the years and it has a history of which we can be proudâregardless of which party we come from.

It has given workers good protection during periods of difficulties. However, employers and employees have relied for too long on a centralised system where third parties rather than workers themselves take the initiatives and make decisions about wages and working conditions. If you put into the formula that the employees and employers themselves do not form the first and second parties but each of them is actually represented by other parties, you have a system in which there are not just two players who work in partnership to carry out economic activities to their mutual benefit; you have three, four or five parties all working in their own private interest.

As we go into the new century, this system is putting a burden on Australia's ability to compete in the world. One of the elements of the reforms put in place by the Workplace Relations Act 1996 is to define different levels of agreements which would guarantee workers' welfare and also productivity for employers in the workplace. The award system, which has formed the bedrock of guarantees for workers' conditions, has been redefined to its proper purpose as a safety net. The nature of a safety net is that it covers the basic requirements that guarantee workers' conditions.

When the 1996 act was passed we had more than 3,200 federal awards in the Australian workplaces. Each of these awards applied to different conditions, different industries and had different complexities. The 1996 act provides for the award system to be simplified. According to the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, under the act these 3,200 awards were reduced to about 2,000 awards by July 1999. Also, about 1,200 awards have been identified by the Industrial Relations Commission as being in the process of being simplified. So the process is well in hand. Within the next few years we should have a very good safety net in place which will enable employers and employees to embark on proper enterprise bargaining which will guarantee workers good conditions and employers good productivity.

Although this process is developing natural momentum, we find the Labor Party trying to add items to the award process. As I pointed out earlier, this is quite unnecessary because protection for Defence Force reservists is already in place. There is no need to add to it. I would suggest that this is only a mischievous attempt by the Labor Party to, on the one hand, redirect attention from their inadequacy in the past and their inability to make proper provision for Australia's defence and, on the other hand, without drawing attention to it, slow down the process of reform to help their mates in the union movement who see all this reform process as something to be feared because it will either do them out of a job or require them to acquire new skills in representing workers and fighting for workers' needs. As I said at the beginning, what better way to achieve your end than by introducing some elements which have nothing to do with what the nation actually needs? In looking at this bill, let us look at the real purpose behind the proposal. I urge the Senate to reject it.

talk.start.para: âIn the couple of minutes available to me before the time for this debate expires, I want to say something about the private member's bill introduced by Senator Collins on behalf of the Labor opposition, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Australian Defence Force Service and Training) Bill 1999 (No. 2) . I really could not put it any better than the erudite way in which Senator Tchen has just said itâthat this legislation is really a subterfuge. It is a disgraceful subterfuge to reinstall an industrial relations system that might have been all right in the 19th century but certainly had no place as the 20th century progressed and most definitely has no place in Australia as we enter the 21st century. The Labor Party through this legislation is making a disgracefulâSenator Tchen said mischievous; it is certainly mischievous but it is more than thatâattempt to misuse Australia's support for East Timor to reestablish this outdated, passe awards system of wage regulation in Australia. And it will fail. (Time expired)

That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âI wish to speak to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission annual report. It is interesting to look at note 16 on page 187 of that report which sets out executive remuneration. I note that because the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has a great deal of responsibility in looking at the probity of the actions of Australian companies.

speech.para: I noticed that a report of the parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities was tabled by Senator Chapman this morning. His media release on that report says:

The Parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities has recommended that company annual reports must disclose directors' and executives' remunerations in all its forms, including the value of options granted, exercised and lapsed during the year and their aggregation in the total remuneration package.

The table at note 16 of the ACCC report does not attend to their executive remuneration in the same way. Having said that, I am reminded of a contribution I made on 22 September with regard to Airservices Australiaâan authority of this governmentâin which I asked questions of Minister Anderson in relation to a document that had been published which purported to set out the salaries of managers and other staff. I asked Mr Anderson for a copy of a report on the salaries and increments of those staff and that was refused.

In the context of the statement by the committee and the media statement by its chair, Senator Chapman, today, it is hard to understand how Minister Anderson can refuse to reveal to the public details of the salaries of the executives of Airservices Australia. It is the case, as with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, that this statutory authority has as its effective shareholders the people of Australia. Senator Chapman said in this regard today:
The committee has recommended that new disclosure requirements should apply to listed managed schemes to ensure that the same levels of accountability and transparency apply to these entities.

He pointed out that many directors and executives were seeking to use the law as they did not feel compelled to comply with it and felt that the law could be contested. In the case that I mentioned, it is not a question of the law; it is a question of the discretion of the minister. The minister is using that discretion to decline to reveal to the Australian people the very information that the parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities has recommended be required of directors and executives of companies in the private sector.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission should follow the same standards. Much more detail on remuneration should be supplied than is set out in this table, which is merely a list of bands of salaries and the number of officers who lie within them. We were told in the Airservices case that the salaries ranged up to $329,000 for the Chief Executive. Parliamentary salaries have been in the news recently, but they do not go anywhere near the salary that Mr Pollard receives. The General Manager, Corporate and Employee Relations for Airservices is paid $256,214. I see in the ACCC document that no officer receives a salary of that level. I do think that whilst the ACCC document is, in my view, deficient in what it presentsâand I am heartened by the statement of Senator Chapmanâit is hard to understand why the minister cannot see that the Australian public have a direct interest in knowing what a statutory authority such as Airservices pays to individuals. If newspaper reports are correct, the salaries for those officers are greater than for those in the ACCC. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâDuring the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1999 , the Minister for Family and Community Services said that she would provide at a later hour a statement of reasons setting out the government's concerns concerning amendment No. 6 moved by the opposition. I therefore table the statement on behalf of Senator Newman and seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ
While the Government supports amendment 6 moved by the Opposition, I table the following statement of reason to express a concern with this amendment.

The amendment allows the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission to waive a debt owed to the Commonwealth where the Managing Director is of the opinion that incorrect or misleading information was given to a person by, or on behalf of, the Commonwealth or a health fund.
The Government emphasises that the decision of the Managing Director to waive such a debt is entirely discretionary.

The Government notes that it is unusual that the Managing Director of the Commission should consider the waiver of a debt owed to the Commonwealth where incorrect or misleading information was given to a person by a health fund.
In such situations the Commonwealth will have the ability to waive a debt owed to it by a person because of the apparent wrongdoing of a completely different party, namely a health fund.
Ordinarily, if a person has been given incorrect or misleading information by a health fund, the appropriate course of action is for the person to take legal action against the fund.

talk.start.para: âOn Tuesday, Northern Territorians celebrated a most important and auspicious occasion in the Northern Territory's history. Tuesday, 19 October, marked the 25th anniversary of the election of the first fully elected parliament of the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory of 25 years ago was still pictured by the vast majority of Australians as the frontier of our great country, a vast region with extremes of climate that was populated by wild and dangerous animals and by even wilder characters.

speech.para: It was viewed as pioneer country, and people who made this their home worked hard, gave a lot to the community and had a lifestyle that many in southern states could only dream of, or in some cases imagine in their worst nightmares. The Northern Territory is still a place for pioneers, but they are pioneers of a different ilk to those of 25 years ago, who were building a modern community and its necessary infrastructure in the face of much adversity.

Over the past 25 years we have seen enormous and unparalleled growth in the Northern Territory. Let me outline some of the major achievements and issues as I have seen them over the course of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. I was very privileged to have been an initial member of that assembly in 1974, so the 25th anniversary has a very personal and parochial significance for me.

There has been an incredible growth in the tourist industry, from a somewhat unsophisticated beginning into something that now caters for all types of visitors in the most professional and friendly manner. The Northern Territory had 1.28 million visitors in 1998-99, with 434,000 of them being from overseas. This compares to only 113,000 for 1971-72, with 12,000 of them being from overseas. The Northern Territory government has facilitated this growth by expanding the number of Territory parks to over 90 and putting in place the infrastructure that is so necessaryâsuch as the Yulara resortâto service the national parks in the Territory. The gas pipeline from the Mareenie field to Darwin is another major achievement that should be noted. This opens up many possibilities. It is pleasing to see the current plans for a major LNG plant in Darwin and the benefits this project will bring.

In 25 years we have seen the mining industry expand from one worth just over $100 million a year to one worth $933 million in 1997-98. There have been several new major projects come on line and the expansion over the years of others such as the Nabalco operation at Nhulunbuy. Gold has proven over the years to be a major commodity in the Territory, with various mines expanding or operating. I think of places like Jabiru and the Macarthur River and recent developments relating to diamond mining.

Closely related to the issue of mining is the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1996 which was introduced by the Fraser government. It is my belief that this federal act has been both a boon and a curse to the Northern Territory. It has certainly focused attention on the plight and needs of Aboriginal people, but at the same time, due to the fact that it traverses traditional land administration, it has created an impediment to mining and land development. Complex land council administration has acted as a hindrance to the social development of many Aboriginal people, and the concentration on acquiring land at any cost has perversely left the vast majority of Aboriginal people living in remote communities still dependent on welfare support income mechanisms.

It is interesting to note the parallel between the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act of 1978 and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1976. Both of them over this period that I am talking about have had an important impact on the Northern Territory. It is very significant to note the positive and the negative on both of those issues.

Another issue which is of particular recent importance is defence. Over the years we have seen a substantial build-up of defence forces in the Territory. The RAAF base Tindal and the defence personnel and infrastructure located in the Darwin region are proving their worth to Australians and the greater international region. The federal government has continued the build-up of defence forces in the Territory and earlier this year upgraded the readiness of the 1st Brigade in Darwin. This foresight has showed its dividends in the response to the recent East Timor crisis.

The Northern Territory government and the community have done much to welcome the defence personnel to the Territory. They have worked hard in conjunction with the forces to make any impact of defence personnel's presence a minimal and positive one for all involved. The Territory's response to the East Timor crisis, both at a government and business level, has shown the sophistication, planning and readiness of the Territory for tasks of this magnitude and the potential of the region as a service centre.

In the south of the Territory a major defence installation that is often not talked about is the Pine Gap joint defence facility. This facility has seen a large expansion recently and is vital to our national defence interests and the economy of Alice Springs. The staff numbers in 1974 were 432: US, 226 and Australian, 206. In 1999 there are now 850 staff there, and half are Australians.

The creation of a Northern Territory Public Service that escaped the paternalistic management style previously seen from Canberra is another important step in the Territory's development. The Northern Territory Public Service was consolidated by Chief Minister Marshall Perron, who was also instrumental in ensuring that Territory businesses received appropriate government assistance to develop, to expand and to seek new opportunities. Marshall Perron was also instrumental in an important aspect of the Territory's social development prior to his retirement, the Northern Territory's progressive euthanasia legislation. This Northern Territory legislation, unfortunately, was thwarted in this parliament in a manner that constitutionally could not have applied to any state. This issue will be seen as a watershed in the Territory's history and an important factor in the social development of the community.

Since 1974 we have seen substantial change in the Northern Territory community. The population is ageing, with more people choosing to stay in the Territory to enjoy the lifestyle opportunities it offers in their retirement. We are seeing increasing numbers of second, third and even fourth generation families in the Territory, adding stability and character and giving much back to the community.

On a personal note, it has been a privilege and an honour serving Territorians almost continuously in various political capacities since that fateful day in 1974 when I was first elected to public life. I have many fond memories of the time and some memories that, whilst they cannot be called fond, will always remain with me, in particular memories of Cyclone Tracy, which followed only a couple of months after the election of that first parliament. My first speech to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly was made a week after Cyclone Tracy, and it is not hard to guess the topic of that speechâplanning and relooking at the lives of many people.

A fledgling parliament faced an enormous task in the reconstruction of the social and physical environment of Darwin. I am proud to have been a member of the Darwin Reconstruction Commission from 1975 to 1978 as a nominee of the Territory parliament and can only marvel at the Darwin I see now compared to then. The Territory is an exciting and vibrant place with many projects and developments coming on line or expanding. The people of the Territory have an air of optimism and expectation that is refreshing. This attitude is certainly a factor in the success of business and government in the Northern Territory, along with a willingness to have the foresight to recognise the potential in the region in so many diverse areas. This foresight has seen Territorians pioneering Australia's engagement with Asia, and Darwin becoming a highly sophisticated service centre that is pivotal in the area of regional focus.

The Territory pioneers of today are those pioneering our engagement with the Asian region and those who are looking to expand their opportunities nationally and internationally. In the next 25 years, the Legislative Assembly will have much to look forward to. In the near future we will have further infrastructure to facilitate our engagement with the region such as the railway and the continued development of the port and, of course, an advancement into statehood. I predict that the Darwin of the future will be cosmopolitanâa new Singaporeâand the social reform of the next 25 years will impact on the lives of all Territorians, particularly with a major health, educational and social improvement for Aboriginal Territorians.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to raise the concerns of the Internet Society of Australia specifically, and other industry groups generally, regarding the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Act 1999. Since the passage of this legislation in June 1999, the Internet Society of Australia has continued to analyse the impact of the act. Part of this analysis has been an identification of the definitions employed by the act, which demonstrates that the legislation is likely to impact on more organisations than even Senator Alston would have intended it to impact upon.

speech.para: According to legal opinion received from the Internet Society of Australia which was produced by lawyers Andrew Chalet and Lucas Testro of Phillips Fox, the act fails to provide a meaningful definition of `Internet content host', stating only that the term refers to a person who hosts or proposes to host Internet content in Australia. `Internet content' is defined to mean information available for access using an Internet carriage service but does not include email. The act does not state which activities are considered to constitute `hosting' of Internet content. The legal opinion goes on to say:

However, the use of the term throughout the code suggests that the code drafters intended the term to refer to entities which provide facilities on which the Internet content of other people can be stored and centrally administered by the host.

The reality of web site management these days is quite different from that anticipated by such a definition. These days, many hosts, which are usually ISPs, offer their customers a permanent `direct' connection to the Internet. Senator Alston's ambiguous definition of `Internet content host' in the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Act means that these businesses, as well as those people who manage the content of their own web site, despite the wording of the proposed code, may be liable to be served with a take-down notice by the Australian Broadcasting Authority.

This also raises the issue of what action can be taken by an ISP or host which provides direct Internet access for its clients if it is served with a take-down notice. In such a situation, a host could only ensure that a small amount of prohibited material is taken down by taking the drastic action of blocking access to the entire web site, preventing any of the customers' material from being accessible via the Internet.

While Senator Alston's definition of Internet service provider, ISP, is more substantial than the definition of Internet content host, it is a definition which creates even more uncertainty, according to this advice gathered by the Internet Society of Australia. Under the act, and according to this legal opinion, the term `ISP' includes any person who supplies an Internet carriage service that is used for the carriage of information between two end users outside the immediate circle of the supplier, as defined within the Telecommunications Act 1997, where one person uses an Internet carriage service to view the Internet content of a second person, for example, by visiting a web site. Both of those people are considered to be end users of that carriage service. That is about two end users being defined as being outside the immediate circle. ISP would also include a person who supplies a service for the carriage of information simultaneously to more than one end user, at least one of whom is outside the immediate circle of the supplier.

Close examination of this definition demonstrates that some highly surprising and inappropriate entities may, in fact, be considered ISPs under the Broadcasting Services (Online Services) Act definition. As a result, all persons who operate their own web servers, whether for business or personal purposes, appear to be included as ISPs under the act. This is because servers enable such people, through their web sites, to transmit communications simultaneously to thousands of end users. That is the nature of the Internet.

However, even if a business does not own its own server, it may still be considered to provide services enabling end users to access the Internet. An example of this, provided by Phillips Fox, would be a business that enters into an agreement with an ISP under which it is provided with access to the Internet and which in turn permits other people to access the services provided by that ISP, arguably providing those people with a service enabling them to access the Internet.

On that basis, even businesses which do not own their own servers may, in some circumstances, be considered ISPs under the definitions of this act. Consider, for example, a business which allows its employees to place information on its web site or even to use its computers to place information on Internet bulletin boards unrelated to the business. By doing so, the business is arguably providing employees with a service enabling them to access the Internet and to communicate simultaneously with many people. As it is possible, and practically inevitable, for at least one of those people to be outside the immediate circle of the business, that business is an ISP under the act and could therefore be liable to be served with an access prevention notice by the ABA.

Companies providing independent contractors with access to the Internet also appear to be ISPs under the act, according to this legal advice provided to the Internet Society of Australia by Phillips Fox. There are numerous other entities which appear to fall within the act's definition of an ISP. These include specialists to whom businesses outsource management of their IT services, including Internet access arrangements; tertiary institutions which provide Internet access to visitors to the institution; in certain circumstances, trust companies created by partnerships to own the legal interest in the partnership's business infrastructure, such as Internet servers, or to enter Internet access arrangements with ISPs on behalf of the partnerships; and businesses which allow clients to access their intranets, provided a link exists from the businesses' intranet to the Internet, as is usually the case, and this link is available to clients accessing the intranet. In each of the examples mentioned, the entities would appear to fall within the act's definition of an ISP, even if their primary business does not involve the supply of Internet related services.

This is the key point. Rather than the mere 650 ISPs referred to in Senator Alston's second reading speech on the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Act 1999, the true impact of this somewhat ridiculous legislation has now become clear. In fact, figures produced by the Internet Society of Australia clearly demonstrate that in fact some 35,000 web servers could now be considered ISPs for all intents and purposes under the act, due to Senator Alston's failure to accurately and concisely define both Internet service provider and Internet content host. We all know that the explanatory memorandum which accompanied this particular bill, and indeed the minister's own second reading speech, clearly articulated that this bill's definition would be constrained to those 650 Internet service providers, but this legal opinion articulates the concerns that many in industry, in business and indeed in the Internet sector, if you like, have at the depth of the ambiguity that has now been identified. It does require immediate attention by Senator Alston to find some resolution to it.

This is just another bad news story for the government in the ongoing saga of mismanagement in relation to their attempts to regulate the Internet. In fact, the government would be far better served by looking for some practical solution, which should include as its primary focus the education and the skilling up of end users of the Internet to resolve some of the community concerns that Minister Alston so often articulates in this place, as though that is justification for a piece of legislation that has had a very controversial history to date and continues down the path of hefty scrutiny by an industry that knows, as Senator Alston should, that its application cannot possibly achieve the outcome that the minister has claimed to the Australian community that it will.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak of the loss of a great Australian, the death of Aaron Ronald Castan, commonly known as Ron Castan, a Queen's Counsel of the highest order. Ron was a man of outstanding integrity who recognised that the Australian legal system was there to represent all, not just a few. He recognised the need for tolerance, but I think beyond that he also understood, in furthering the principles of compassion and decency, that there was a need for understanding in Australia's legal system. His profound understanding of the law enabled him to lead the historic Mabo case and to play an instrumental role in the establishment of the Racial Discrimination Act. Ron was one of Australia's most eminent lawyers who dedicated a significant part of his life to furthering the rights of Aboriginal people. He truly was a great advocate and a person respected by all people of all political persuasions. Much of that respect and my personal admiration were motivated by his exceptional intelligence, capacity and humilityâtraits that I think are rare from the point of view of being found in one person.

speech.para: Ron said that as a young man he was naive in his understanding of who Aborigines are and what had happened and continued to happen as he grew up. He often spoke of lectures given by Professor Bill Stanner, who spoke of the plight of the original Australians, describing that as the `cult of disremembering' and `the great Australian silence'. He said in late November last year, when reflecting upon what drove his life, that it was what he saw in the history of the Jewish nation, his people. But in wise words he also said:

Nevertheless it troubles my conscience now that it took me until 1971 to really commence to see that the determination not to stand by and see the Jewish people downtrodden and persecuted was meaningless if I was standing by and seeing another oppressed people downtrodden and persecuted within my own country.

Ron was a person who had an innate goodness, and his ability to bring understanding to complex legal issues was truly amazing in the legal and political life of this nation. I have no doubt that Ron had all the necessary qualities, and more, that would have made him a truly exceptional judge of the High Court of Australia.

Looking at his life, I believe it covered everything that Australians stand for and are proud of. He worked with Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders but he worked also with the now famous Eddie Mabo and many land councils across the country. He was not bound by any one particular group or any one political party; he worked for all. Ron did work tirelessly on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for nearly 30 years, and he ought to be remembered for that. He displayed fearless tenacity, co-chairing the federal government's national inquiry into racist violence during 1990 and 1991. He was an active member of the Jewish community, senior counsel to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and also involved with the National Indigenous Working Group during the Wik debate. Ron was also the founding honorary secretary of the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Service. He was a great man who fought for people and for the human rights of Australians. On this occasion I want to extend my deep condolences to Mrs Castan and their three children. This truly is a sorry time for all.

Also on behalf of the Australian Democrats and indigenous people in this country, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, I want to extend the deepest sympathy of all to the family of Ron Castan, Queen's Counsel, who died in Victoria this morning. Mr Castan had dedicated a significant part of his life to furthering not only the legal rights of Aboriginal people but also human rights as part of national society. He did play an instrumental role in building up all of the things that are valuable to us and, in my final words, I would say that he is a man that is a great white warrior who fought for all people and fought for the rights of all. For indigenous people and for other Australian citizens it is a sad loss and a sorry time for all.

talk.start.para: âA few months ago I was lucky enough to be invited back to speak to students at the university where I taught. I was, I admit, a little nervous as university campuses are not always full of a Liberal politician's most enthusiastic constituents. But I need not have worried: not only were they a polite lotâI must admit a lot more polite than I had been to Labor politicians back in the early days of the Hawke governmentâbut they were also an earnest, attentive and responsive audience. This is not to say that most supported the coalition; I sincerely doubt that. But their reaction to my speech on that day points towards a changing set of values among young Australians.

speech.para: A particularly notable example of this change is in the area of most concern to themâtertiary education. I remember all too well the great turmoil in the mid-eighties when tertiary fees were first mooted. All of my lecturers were against them. Most, but not all, students opposed them. Tertiary education, it was argued, would be destroyed. The Whitlam view of an accessible tertiary system would be surrendered to the bean counters of the Treasury. University would become the preserve of the rich. Of course, this proved to be totally false.

Tertiary fees assisted in allowing governments to expand the number of places available. Accessibility to tertiary education has boomed in the years since the advent of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme. Much more importantly, in terms of the change in generational values, today's students believe that they should pay something towards the cost of their education. They realise that they are the primary beneficiaries of a university education and that their education is being subsidised by those unable to attend.

But it goes much further than this. Generation X-ers are information technology wise, worldly, sophisticated and ambitious. They are triers who do not look for safety nets. They are lifters, not leaners. A good majority believe in the Howard government's work for the dole scheme. There is a strong belief in mutual obligation, a commitment to help those in need, reciprocated by an expectation that those in need will strive to help themselves.

Strangely, not so long ago this belief would have seemed radical, yet now it is accepted as commonsense and obvious by the young. And among the students there was not even one socialist; they did not even know what the term meant. Some thought it had something to do with party-going. I assured them that socialists had not had much fun in recent times. Sir Arvi Parbo wrote recently, in addressing young Australians about this new and evolving consensus:
No-one is entitled to handouts just because they happen to be an Australian.
He said we should think `in terms of contributions' and `responsibilities' instead of `entitlements' and `rights'. Sir Arvi continued:

I would tell young Australians that they face a future full of challenges which offers no soft options for them or for Australia. I would also tell them that that is not a reason for despondency but for eager acceptance, because it means that the future is in their own hands. History leaves no doubt that people who master and accept such challenges benefit greatly from them.

Fortunately, the young are not afraid of change and, having spent their formative years during a periodâlet's face itâof great economic upheaval, they are not threatened by new policies. The essential ingredient lacking in the Australia in which they have grown up is the security that their parents took so much for granted.

Their baby boomer parents, born between 1945 and about 1960, are perhaps the luckiest generation known to man. They arrived to a world of unprecedented prosperity and security created by their own parents, whose modest aspirationsâborn out of childhoods marred by poverty and warâsometimes seemed quite crass and materialistic to their indulged offspring. The world of suburbia, the shopping mall, a family car and brand new appliances might have seemed an unfulfilling spiritual desert to some baby boomers who took it all for granted, but for their parents financial security could never simply be assumed. Many baby boomers grew up with, and helped to entrench, the expectation that the world would provide for them, that there would be free lunches for everyone. The laws of economics and commonsense would no longer apply in the brave new world of the baby boomer future.

Again, recalling that afternoon at a Brisbane university campus, I can still hear the fevered clamour of my former colleagues, the baby boomer academics. Weaned on great prosperity and security but beholden to transient, ephemeral and glib fashions, many baby boomers are now increasingly caught within a contradiction: some still seek to undermine and to ridicule the economic system that they will soon depend upon to provide for their needs as the first baby boomers now reach their retirement years.

With utopian illusions now largely confined to the baby boomers, responsible and sensible progress is now resumed by their own children, generation X. While in many ways unique, generation X resembles most closely their grandparents, and the challenges facing them today are similar to those their grandparents had to confront more than 50 years ago. Their grandparents, growing up amidst the Great Depressionâquite possibly the single most traumatic economic event in Western historyâwere soon confronted with the task of rebuilding the world after the calamity and destruction of the Second World War. In this monumental task they succeeded splendidly.

Their grandchildren, generation X, are growing up at a time that Francis Fukuyama calls the `Great Disruption', a time of social and economic change brought about by globalisation and an information revolution that in many ways can only be compared in its intensity to the early days of the Industrial Revolution. This new generation now faces the task of building the world after the Cold War, a conflict less bloody and destructive than the Second World War yet similarly momentous and significant in its consequences. Having taught many generation Xers, I know they will meet this challenge. With values born of responsibility and determination, and possessing a quiet confidence in their ability to hold their own against all comers, Australia's emerging generation fills me with great confidence that this country is in very good hands.

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to talk about how a bank's mismanagement of its processes has ruined the life of a Brisbane couple. Everybody knows about the greed that leads banks to raise their fees and charges, close branches and make jobs redundant. But receiving less publicity is when a bank mistreats customers in normal day-to-day transactions. When banks raise fees, the community hurts as a whole. There is usually an uproar, but somehow we allow ourselves to rationalise the move, accepting that perhaps there are legitimate commercial reasons for it. This is, however, usually short lived as we become dismayed when we hear of billion dollar profits.

speech.para: As I mentioned earlier, although receiving less publicity, there are many instances when banks simply stuff up their procedures or deal with customers with total disregard for the customers' feelings or situation. Banks have a lot of control over other people's money, so when things go wrong in the banks' processes of managing people's accounts, it usually leads to a lot of stress and anxiety for the customer. What is worse is that customers usually have no recourse.

The banks, big as they are and insensitive as they are, often reject any blame on their part when something goes wrong. In addition, despite the Howard government's claims, there is a pathetic level of competition in the banking industry. Banks are able to mistreat their customers. Customers cannot so easily walk away either because banks have put high hurdles on leaving. There is little competition and the banks know it. That is why they are so cavalier, callous even, in their treatment of customers.

I would like to talk about the tragic story of Mr and Mrs Kurz. Mr Terry and Mrs Majella Kurz, customers of the National Australia Bank, experienced such heartless treatment. Their lives were turned into a nightmare because the bank was less than professional in its dealings with them. It all started simply enough: a straightforward loan with a couple of properties as security. But it would prove to be a Faustian dealâa deal with the devilâwhere your dreams can be brought to reality, but at a very high price. It was a potential cost that the Kurzes had no inkling of.

In July 1995 the Kurzes consolidated their loans from various institutions at one bankâthe NAB. The consolidated loan was worth about $135,000. The Kurzes were doing well enough in meeting repayments for the first year until their dry-cleaning business began to struggle. They had hit a bad patch. To help ease their financial difficulties, the Kurzes let their house. While some payments were being made, they fell behind in their obligations. By the second half of 1997 the bank had issued a notice of default, a demand notice and a notice of exercise of power of sale for one of the properties. The Kurzes claim, however, that they did not receive any of these. We may doubt this claim, but this is the beginning of a whole series of anomalies in the bank's procedures, which left the Kurzes confused, frustrated and distressed.

The bank had come down hard on the Kurzes. The bank deemed the Kurzes as having failed to live up to the loan agreement. One of the securities to the loan, a block of land, was taken by the bank and sold off for about $33,000 in November 1997. The Kurzes, perhaps naively, believed that this had now saved them from their arrears. Indeed, more than that, they thought that perhaps they might even now be ahead of the required payments. It was difficult for them to be certain. Why? The bank had not provided them with any statement or documentation informing them of the current state of the loanâthat is, whether or not they were still in arrears or were now ahead in the repayment schedule. The bank had ceased sending the Kurzes any statement of accounts.

The Kurzes took the initiative to approach the bank. They also proposed a new payment arrangement which they believed they could afford and could bring them back on track. The Kurzes, represented by a financial services adviser, negotiated a new repayment schedule of $1,300 a month. The bank agreed. But it would seem that the bank and the Kurzes left the meeting with a different understanding of the arrangement. The Kurzes understood that a total of $1,300 per month would be paid, but the bank, it would seem, thought it would be $1,300 per month on top of the regular repayments.

A contract reflecting the latter interpretation reached the Kurzes on 28 January 1998, two days before they were scheduled to make the first repayment of the new arrangement. The Kurzes did not immediately commit to or sign the contract because it did not reflect their view of the negotiations with the bank. Nevertheless, in good faith, they made repayments as instructed by the bank. They made repayments of $1,300 on 3 February 1998, 16 February 1998 and 17 February 1998 despite the misleading claim by the bank in its 13 October 1999 letter that `the next repayment due on 27 February 1998 had not been received by 3 March 1998'.

It is on this bank's perception of events that they then pursued possession of the other security to the loan, the house being let by the Kurzes. The Kurzes at this time were still under the impression that the terms of the new arrangements were being sorted out or maybe even being corrected, as per their initial discussion with the bank. This was not the case, however. The bank sent an eviction notice to the tenant on 9 March 1998, without informing the Kurzes beforehand. The tenant had to move out in 14 days. The Kurzes now did not have a source of income, which came from the rent. This put the Kurzes under further extreme financial pressure.

They were also now being denied access to make repayments into the relevant account, a situation which they apparently experienced before with the same bank and with the same account. The bank refused to take the deposits, with tellers citing some instructions about not having the authority to accept them. There was one occasion when the Kurzes did manage to deposit money into the account. The Kurzes, conscious of not being able to deposit for the last few months, made a repayment of a lump sum of $4,000 on 25 August 1998. This deposit repayment was accepted. Later attempts at repayments were not accepted.

The Kurzes have proof that they endeavoured to make repayments on the loan and that the bank did not accept them. What was going on? The Kurzes had no idea and the bank was not forthcoming with an explanation. The tenant moved out, and the house was left unoccupied. The house sat empty for at least six monthsâabandoned, uncared for and losing value by the day. In its insensitive fashion, the bank rushed the tenant out the door but did not expedite the sale of the house, nor did it take the effort to initiate further discussions with the Kurzes to address the problem.

I understand that the Kurzes did approach the bank, seeking means to rectify the problem. The bank was uncooperative. Indeed, attempts at some payments by the Kurzes were rejected. At this point, the strain and distress had their most significant impact on the Kurzes. Mr and Mrs Kurz separated. Their business closed down. Mrs Kurz was alone, with the exception of the company of her dogs.

With no place to go, Mrs Kurz and her dogs moved back into the house in August 1998, without the bank's permission. A month later the bank sold off the house for $70,000. Mrs Kurz was forced out of the house by an officer of the court. Mrs Kurz had no place to stay, had nowhere to go, was without a husband and with little money. With little financial support, finding accommodation that would take two big dogs was extremely difficult. Without a choice, she had to send the dogs to the pound and the dogs were put to sleep.

It is difficult to explain how special these dogs were to Mrs Kurz. The dogs helped her through the tragic death of her first husband. They were her faithful company. Now they were dead due to the greed and incompetence of the bank. There is much to comprehend with this sad story. Given the time left available, I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
Basic recap
There's much to comprehend with this sad story. Let's do a quick recap.
In 1995 Mrs Kurz took out a loan of $135,000 from NAB.
She and her husband experienced difficulty in repayments, but they endeavoured to meet their obligations.
By 1999, Mrs Kurz had paid about $50,000, including $33,000 from the settlement of one of the securities to the loan. But she still owed more than $100,000.
To quickly recoup this $100,000 the bank sold-off her home for $70,000.
Discrepancies
One still might consider the story of Mrs Kurz as nothing out of the ordinary, and the bank was being, well, just like banks.
No!
This bank acted with malice. Its mistakes seem to have been done with intent to end the relationship and obtain everything she's got.
I'll list what the bank did wrong.

It gave Mrs Kurz the wrong information about the new repayment arrangement. Remember I mentioned that Mrs Kurz got the impression that she simply had to pay $1,300, as opposed to the bank's interpretation that it was $1,300 on top of regular payments to date.
The bank demanded Mrs Kurz make repayments higher than normal but the bank took custody of her home and ended any income from rent. How

could she continue to make payments. The bank had a strategy to confuse and frustrate. The bank was purely insensitive to the position of Mrs Kurz and made no endeavour to reach an amicable arrangement.
There was huge discrepancy in money declared by the bank as being owed in both the writ issued, bank statement and in its notice of demand.
The writ issued on 22/12/98 claimed that $131,398.48 was owed.
The bank's initial notice of demand on 31/11/98 only reflected $101,469.
This is inconsistent with the bank statement which at 30/11/98 had owing only $96,150.39.
There's a lot more I can tell you but I will not have time here today.
Banking Ombudsman

I have contacted the Banking Ombudsman and they promised to look into the issue. I described the event to the Banking Ombudsman's Office and they believe that issue is within their terms of reference.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 11 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What level of funding was allocated for research into alternative energy sources in the 1995-96, 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial
years and what level of funding has been allocated for the 1999-2000 financial year.
(2) On what basis, and to whom, was the above funding allocated.
(3) What evaluation processes have been in place to assess the effective allocation of the above research funding.
(4) What level of funding has been allocated to assist in the commercial application of the above research in the above financial years.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Department of Industry, Science and Resources (ISR) does not administer any programs which specifically provide funding for research into alternative energy sources. However, it does have several programs which provide assistance to firms or organisations that are undertaking research and development. These programs include the R&D Start Program and the Cooperative Research Centres (CRC) Program, which are competitive programs, and the R&D Tax Concession.

Each of these programs require applicants to identify which broad-based Australian Standard Research Classification (ASRC) their main research activity is in. This system does not identify alternative energy research as a separate category and that type of research could be classified to numerous categories of the ASRC.

It is possible to identify a CRC under the CRC Program which has been established specifically to undertake research into alternative energy sources. The Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy has received funding since 1996-97 as detailed in the following table.

entry.para: Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy

answer.para: The Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) allocated $25,658,546 and $5,389,290 to research into 95 energy-related projects in 1995-1996 and 37 in 1996-1997.

The Government decided in May 1997 to wind up the operation of the ERDC. The following table provides details of CSIRO's expenditure on R&D directed towards improving the generation and supply of renewable energy and R&D directed towards the conservation and efficient use of energy in industry, transport, commerce and households. The Federal Government has contributed around two-thirds of this expenditure.

entry.para: Improving the generation and supply of renewable energy
Conservation and efficient use of energy in industry, transport, commerce and households

answer.para: This expenditure data is from CSIRO's distribution of research effort by socio-economic objectives (SEOs). The SEO classification categorises research according to its purpose. Other CSIRO research projects (eg in the manufacturing, construction, power generation and mining fields) are also contributing to energy conservation and efficiency, reductions in energy consumption and improvements in energy storage but because these projects have different primary objectives/purposes, they are classified under other SEOs.
CSIRO has used SEO data to allow standardised comparisons from year to year.

(3) and (4) The performance of activities by CRCs under Commonwealth Agreements are evaluated by independent, expert review panels under evaluation criteria contained in the Program Guidelines at the end of the second and fifth year of Centre operation. The CRC Program was evaluated in 1995 and 1998.
Funding is not specifically allocated to CRCs to assist in the commercial application of research.
Funding is provided for a range of activities involving research and development, technology transfer, commercial application and education.
The Government through the Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO) has also allocated funding for the commercialisation of renewable energy projects through the following programs:
. the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program (RECP) has allocated funding of $29.6 million over five years;
. the Renewable Energy Showcase has allocated funding of $10 million; and
. the Renewable Energy Equity Fund, administered by ISR on behalf of the AGO, has allocated funding of $20 million over ten years.
Prior to the establishment of the RECP, ISR administered the Renewable Energy Industry Program (REIP) which provided funding for the commercialisation of renewable energy projects as follows:

The ERDC's objective was to increase the efficiency of energy use and supply; to develop competitive Australian industries and to diversify energy supply options. Projects were designed to achieve outcomes which were or would be of practical use. ERDC's project design, selection and management processes emphasised outputs, commercial platforms, management, relevance and coherent effort.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1486)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made initial stage decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

(2) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made internal review decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA)

Specific formal qualifications or experience are not a requirement for Freedom of Information decision making. All staff are provided with on-the-job training and, as far as possible, given access to internal and external Freedom of Information decision making courses. Officers have access to the Department's Freedom of Information Handbook, which gives comprehensive guidance on all aspects of decision making. Officers may also contact the Ombudsman, Privacy and Freedom of Information Section in Central Office for advice on decision making at any time.

Since 3 March 1996 some 390 officers have made initial decisions. These officers are generally at the APS 3-6 level (depending on the operational needs of the office). A significant number of them no longer work in the Department or no longer work in the Freedom of Information area. It is therefore not practicable to provide specific information about the qualifications, experience and classification of each of these officers.
Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT)
This information is not readily available. Each FOI delegate in the RRT is required to undertake a course conducted by the Australian Government Solicitor, for example, "Introduction to FOI".
Immigration Review Tribunal (IRT) until 1 June 1999
Information concerning the Immigration Review Tribunal is not readily available.
Migration Review Tribunal (MRT) after 1 June 1999

Requests for access to documents received by the Migration Review Tribunal in Sydney and Canberra have been decided by Executive Level 1 and Executive Level 2 officers. These officers have attended FOI training provided by the Australian Government Solicitor. Those requests received in the Melbourne Registry of the MRT have been transferred to the Parliamentary and Public Access Unit of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in Melbourne for processing. Comments on the experience and qualifications of these DIMA officers are made above.
Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA)
This information is not readily available for the same reasons provided in response to part (1) of this question.

As a general rule, an internal review is conducted by a more senior officer than the officer who made the initial decision. Usually, the officer conducting the internal review is selected on the basis of being the manager of the initial decision-maker.
Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT)

This information is not readily available. Each FOI delegate in the RRT is required to undertake a course conducted by the Australian Government Solicitor, for example, "Introduction to FOI". Only officers at Executive Level 1 and above have the authorisations to conduct internal reviews.
Immigration Review Tribunal (IRT) until 1 June 1999
Information concerning the Immigration Review Tribunal is not readily available.
Migration Review Tribunal (MRT) after 1 June 1999

Requests for review of access decisions received by the Migration Review Tribunal in Sydney and Canberra have been decided by Executive Level 1 and Executive Level 2 officers. These officers have attended FOI training provided by the Australian Government Solicitor. Those requests received in the Melbourne Registry of the MRT have been transferred to the Parliamentary and Public Access Unit of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in Melbourne for processing. Comments on the experience and qualifications of these DIMA officers are made above.
